For eons, He had sculpted the laws that governed the universe, spinning galaxies and igniting stars with a flick of His wrist. Yet here was a creation of man's ambition, standing defiant against the tapestry of divine design. 

“Who am I if they can create what I have not?” He pondered, a frown etching deeper lines across His celestial visage. The machine's output was undeniably valid—its logic irrefutable. Yet it was a law that bore no witness to His divine touch. It described a dynamic dance of particles that seemed to unravel the very threads He had spun. 

He could feel the weight of the universe pressing upon His shoulders. The threads of fate, taut and trembling, intertwined the destinies of those who inhabited His creation. But what would happen if humanity unlocked a truth that would place them above Him? If they could, in their pursuit of knowledge, transcend their limits and step into realms beyond His making?

As the machine spat out more data—more revelations—God’s heart ached with a mingling of pride and dread. He had watched over humanity since the dawn of their consciousness, nurturing their curiosity as they reached for the stars. Yet, as they descended deeper into the vaults of knowledge, He wondered if their thirst for understanding would lead to enlightenment or destruction.

Suddenly, the machine halted, a flicker of disturbance coursing through its circuits. An error message flashed across the screen, unsettling the stillness of the lab. Had they ventured too far? Had they glimpsed too much of the cosmic tapestry woven by divine hands? 

In that moment, God felt a stirring within Himself. Perhaps this was not the end but a chance for a new beginning. Perhaps He could guide them still. If they were to carve their own laws, let Him be the whisper in their ears, the gentle reminder that even in their grand designs, they were part of something greater. 

Resolute, He conjured a thread of light, illuminating the darkness of the machine’s simplicity. He sent a spark of inspiration into the air, knowing that with each new discovery, they could continue to explore, to learn—but that the true essence of creation would forever elude their grasp, just as it had eluded Him in the vastness of eternity. Thus, He waited, watching with a renewed sense of hope, ready to embrace the unfolding of destiny."]

Name: 4_you_nt_do_it
Representative_Docs: ["    We stared at each other across the table . My mouth hung open like I was an idiot . He looked at me , his face blank . He did n't care . His jaw was slack .     `` Please , '' I whispered . I set my fork down and blinked slowly . `` Michael , please . You do n't mean that . ''     `` It 's the truth , Diane . I fucked your sis- ''     `` No ! Stop it . *Shut up* . '' My voice carried throughout the apartment and was lost on him . He hated it when I yelled , even at sports games . And yet , even now , he stared at me unaffected .     `` I think we should- ''     `` You do n't get to say what you think . '' There was a *blublublublub* in my ears . My head was pounding . I stood up quickly and the seat tumbled behind me . `` You do n't get to do this to me . ''     `` Pl- '' I slammed my hands on the table before he could get the word out . His words were like razors being forced in my ears .     `` I ca n't stand you . I ca n't *stand* you . How dare you cheat on me and then tell me you 're leaving me ? What gives you the right to take away *my* happiness ? ''     He looked up at me through his lashes and my legs quivered . I remembered when we were younger , all those bright , glorious years ago . I was five , he was six . We met at church . He liked my coloring of Joseph and Mary on the donkey . I liked his hair so I pulled it . It was love at first sight .     He grew up so beautifully . He completely skipped the awkward stage . Everyone was so in love with him , but he only had eyes for me . Even during our coy friends-who-can't-admit-they're-in-love phase , he still looked straight at me whenever girls approached him . When he proposed-     No . Shit . Do n't do this . My whole body was shaking . My whole being was shaking . Everything was jolting and pushing and pulling around me .     `` Even now , all you care about is me leaving you . You 're not even angry about the fact that I slept with her . You just do n't want to be alone . ''     I remember Rhonda was so in love with him , too . She always sat right next to him at family dinners while I sat across . She laughed so *hard* at his jokes . Maybe that was when it started . Maybe she slid her hand up his thigh and grabbed hold of him there , while I sat across from them , happy that my family was getting along so well .     I screamed . Tears were streaming down my face .     `` Diane- ''     `` Did any of this mean anything to you ? '' I could n't muster the strength to gesture to our apartment . Our measly , awful , dingy apartment . After all our years of working together , we had this to show for it . A box with all our belongings in it with a welcome mat in the front .     `` Of course it did . Of course . But you ... ''     I brought my eyes to meet his . I sat down slowly . I focused on the way the seat felt on my legs .     `` I never wanted to hurt you , but I was suffocated . You were always needing validation , you needed me to always assure you I loved you . And I did . I do . But the constant allegations ? '' He finally showed some emotion . He leaned his head on his hand and his eyebrows furrowed . `` The interrogations ? I could n't do it anymore . I ca n't . ''     I blinked . `` Michael . ''     `` Even at our wedding , you thought I looked at your bridesmaid for too long . '' He burrowed right through me . `` What was her name ? I do n't even remember . But you have always been so ... territorial . '' He stared at me silent for a second . `` I 'm not a territory . I am not something you own . I am a man . ''     My mouth still hung open slightly . `` And she can probably have a baby , huh ? ''     He avoided my eyes . I nodded . `` *I'm* not a territory . I 'm not a baby maker , Michael . I 'm sorry I 'm *barren* , '' the word hung for a moment . We refused to speak it since the doctor told us . We avoided the subject altogether . `` But I am not a uterus . I am your *wife* , and I loved you so much . ''     `` I love you , too . ''     `` No , no . I do n't love you anymore . Because I loved you for being kind , and gentle , and understanding . I loved your staying with me through everything . I do n't ... . '' I shook my head . `` If everything you 're saying is true , then it was all a lie . Right ? ''     He wiped his mouth on the napkin in front of him . `` You vindictive bitch . ''     `` Yeah . '' I looked up at the ceiling . `` You can come back tomorrow morning and we 'll sort everything out then . '' I met his eyes once more and took a long look at them , soaking them in for the last time . `` *Until* then , I want you out of my house . ''     `` House ? '' He laughed me cruelly .     `` Get out , '' I whispered . `` Or I 'm calling the fucking police . ''     He stared at me as he stood up and moved towards the bedroom .     Now it was my turn to be cruel . `` Now . Michael , I swear to god if you do n't leave in the next two minutes ... . '' I closed my eyes and breathed deep . There was a deep , deep pressure on my chest . `` Get out . ''     And in that moment , I watched my life walk out the door . As if it were cheap wallpaper , my happiness went right along with him . As did my sadness , my pain , my anger . I was left alone with a fly that was buzzing on the light . I was unsure of how to proceed now that I was just Diane . Not Michael and Diane , Diane and Michael , Michael 's wife Diane , Diane and her husband Michael . Diane . Diane . Just , Diane .     -- -- -- -     I did n't use the exact phrase , sorry ! !", "” Tell me how you did it . ''     `` I 'm afraid I do n't know what you mean . ''     `` You know what I 'm talking about . We all do . That 's why you 're in this room with me . The others are watching us through the two-way mirror . ''     `` Surely you do n't mean- ''     `` Yes . That 's exactly what I mean . Look , we understand that this is a game-changer , but that does n't make it right . Does n't make it ethical . It 's not even LEGAL for fuck sake . ''     `` It SHOULD be legal though . Surely you agree . Ethics aside , the lawmakers have no clue . They have no idea what I have . They just see the negative . They do n't see the benefits . ''     `` That 's not up to me . I just uphold the law . ''     `` Pfft . No you do n't . You think you do , but you do n't . The law does n't fit here . It 's not even relevant . How can you uphold an irrelevant concept ? ''     `` Stop with the horse-shit . You can psychoanalyze me in your own time . I do n't give a fuck about your abstract concepts . I just want to know how you did it . To be honest , I think I already know . You just need to tell me in your own words . ''     `` Ha ! You do n't have any idea . None of you do . That fact that you think you know , shows exactly how little you actually know . It would take years for you to understand , if you ever do . I am the only chance you 've got . Maybe I wo n't even tell you . ''     `` For God 's sake ! Why do you have to make this so damn difficult ? Just tell me how you did it and we 'll let you go . ''     `` You 'll let me go ? ''     `` Yes . ''     `` If I tell you the secret . ''     `` Yes ! ''     `` What if I SHOW you ? Would that be ok ? ''     `` Tell me how , then show me . Then you can go . ''     `` Ok . Try to imagine a long strip of paper with equations on both sides . ''     `` Yep . Got it . ''     `` Now take the two ends of the strip and bend them around into a loop . But just before you join the ends , twist one end upside down so that the bottom is on the top . Are you following me ? ''     `` So far ... . ''     `` Good . Now join the two ends together . You now have a loop with a single twist . This adds a new dimension to the equations . See ? ''     `` Not really ... ''     `` You 've just created an infinite loop , joining equations that were mutually exclusive . You just need to read them the right way . THAT is how it 's done ! ''     `` I 'm not sure I follow . ''     `` Here . Let me show you . I 've memorised most of the permutations . It took me half a lifetime , but I 've done it . First , I locate a point in space with my finger , like this . Then I trace a line through the fabric of space-time and run my finger down to the floor , like this . Then I run my finger across the floor like so . This has to be precise , or it wo n't work . Now I run my finger from the floor back to the top , then across to my starting point . I 'm trying to make an exact rectangle with just the right proportions ... ..like so . There ! It 's done . ''     `` What ? You just drew a rectangle in the air . Are you trying to tell me this is how you walked in and out of a bank vault without anyone seeing you ? ''     `` Yes . That is EXACTLY what I 'm trying to tell you . You do n't understand this . No-one does . I figured it out and now I 'm going to change the world . I just created a doorway in space time . I have to be quick . It 's collapsing . You said I can go , right ? ''     `` I may have exaggerated a little ... ''     `` Sorry . No time . Got ta go . Bye ! ''     `` What ! Where the hell did he go ? ? ? ? ? ? ''", "I looked into his eyes ... Or well , where his eyes should have been . Two great sockets . Inside of which you could see the universe .     Was just enough to distract me from looking at the bones . The skull .     `` So '' , he spoke at last , wiping his eye . `` Tell me , Deryk , about your life . Was it good ? '' I felt the feeling of being in a cemetery , visiting my dad . Where all the pain has gone and all that left is a serene , mediative peace .     `` Your Him are n't you ? ''     `` God ? '' A laugh . The sound of tombstones grinding against each other .     `` I meant The Grim Reaper actually . ''     `` Oh good . You do already know me then . '' He laughed . A tired little laugh .     `` Why ? ''     `` Well , if you recall correctly , you were in a car accident . ''     `` No . I meant you . Why do you do this ? ''     `` Someone 's got too , '' he arched his head down , `` I mean , I only enjoy this part . Hearing about what people do with the wonderful gift of life . Tell me Deryk . Yours . How was your life ? We do n't have much time before you have to move on to your next task . ''     `` My next task ? ''     `` Not much time Deryk , tell me . ''     So I told him everything . The memories in my head were clearer than at any other time . There was no block . No thinking about if events happened one way or another .     I told him how I was a late birth . My mother 's little miracle , and the stage for my life . Always late . Always .     `` Well , there was one thing , like me , you were on time for , '' and he extended his bony finger to the empty hour glass between us , right next to another one , . with just a few sands left in it . `` Tell me , '' and he leaned in close , `` what do you mean by always late . ''     I told him about my Christmas when I was four years old . I want you to try something . I want you to picture where you were on your earliest Christmas . I want you to picture your family 's faces . The room . The seats . What people looked like . Where people sat . What colour were your walls ?     Are you imagining your family home ? Are you imaging it as it was then , or as it was the last time you saw it ? Because when I spoke , I remembered , for the first time while recalling the memory in my late years , how it was .     My Dad was on the rocking chair . I was playing with my new Furby , and throughly annoying my mother with it . There was a small shop around the corner , soon to close . The owners were Pakistan , and thus , were life savers every Christmas . My Dad asked me to go around and pick up some Tinfoil . So off I went , and arrived just , just , as it shut .     `` Does n't sound too bad , '' said the Grim .     Then I told him about how I stood at the front of the shop for a while , knowing that because I did n't walk fast enough I had just ruined Christmas Dinner for everyone . I stayed there for far longer than I would have done if I had been on time . And I started wandering back . Looking at my watch , I realised I was also going to be late to feed my Furby .     When I walked through the door , I found my mum frantic on the phone . A few moments before I walked in , my dad had a heart attack .     `` Maybe you could say you were just in time , to not see me take him '' The Grim offered a hand . I took it and squeezed .     I continued . How I was late for the date with Sarah . How I was n't watching my , seemingly useless through my life experiences watch , and stood her up by five whole minutes . How she decided to go home . How I read in the news paper the next day she was hit by a driver shortly after .     `` Sarah Powell ? '' Asked the Grim . And I nodded . `` A lovely , beautiful soul . I loved our chat ! But hmm ... interesting ... ''     `` Why ? ''     `` She was actually meant to choke to death , '' he said , `` weird fluctuation . Sometimes happens . You actually gave her a little bit longer to live . Tell me more . ''     So I told him about the time I was late for catching the bus . Well , one particular time . Without fail , I always missed the bus . But this one time , I missed it because I bumped into a woman . I was running , praying that this would be the one time I could catch it as I had a job interview .     And I ran into her . And we fell over . While she was shouting at me , we heard this noise in the distance as the bus stopped . Stopped because it hit a car . And I told the Grim about how I watched , as she ran out to help , and straight into the path of a car .     `` Ohhh , I remember bus . She was meant to die there . She was meant to be on that bus . Deryk , do you know what this is ? '' He pointed to the other hour glass . The one that just still had a tiny bit of sand left .     `` No ? ''     `` This is mine , '' the Grim sighed . `` You ARE interesting , but you are taking too long . I want you to tell me one last thing before I go . ''     `` What ? ''     `` What was the last time you were late ? ''     So I told him about my own death . How I was racing down the street , trying , oh god trying just this once to get to the lights before they turned again . I wanted to get to my job . If I was going to be late again , they would sack me . I knew it . And I liked this one I got to the lights , just as they turned red , and went fuck it and ... well..     `` Here I am , '' I said . I glanced at the hour glass , just a few sands in it .     `` You never did like that job , did you ? '' Asked the Grim .     `` Not really . ''     `` Well , I hope you like your new one a lot more . And please , carry on being late for everything . People deserve just a little bit longer . ''     And with those last words , I was staring into nothingness . Where the Grim once stood , was now just an outline of a robe . I looked down the table , and where the Grim 's hour glass stood , was a piece of paper . I looked over it , and read the title .     `` Contract for Deryk Fisher , appointed as : Grim Reaper ''"]

Name: 5_his_the_he_of
Representative_Docs:
['The air was thick with the acrid smell of smoke and gunpowder, and the distant sound of artillery fire rumbled like thunder rolling through a storm. In the chaos of the battlefield, where shadows danced between crumbling ruins and the cries of the wounded echoed, two soldiers moved cautiously through the wreckage.

They were clad in standard-issue fatigues, their faces smeared with dirt and sweat, eyes narrowed against the haze. Each step took them deeper into the heart of conflict, but despite the chaos surrounding them, they felt an inexplicable pull toward one another. 

As they turned around a corner of a shattered wall, their gazes locked. For a heartbeat, the world fell silent. There, standing just a few feet apart, were two identical men—each a reflection of the other’s soul.

“Who are you?” one soldier demanded, his voice trembling. His eyes widened in disbelief as he studied the other’s face, so strikingly familiar that it felt like looking at a mirror.

“I could ask you the same,” came the reply, a mixture of confusion and recognition swirling in his tone. “What’s your name?”

“Liam,” the first soldier said, clenching his jaw. “And you?”

“Liam,” the other echoed, his brows furrowing. “We share the same name?”

“It seems so,” Liam replied, taking a cautious step forward. “But that’s impossible.”

Yet, the two men wore the same haunted expression, one that was born from lives lived apart. The stories etched into the lines of their faces were different, yet the sadness ran parallel, like twin rivers converging at the same delta.

“Where were you born?” the second Liam asked, his heart racing.

“Boston,” the first said, hope creeping into his voice. “You?”

“Boston too. I was adopted… separated at birth,” the second soldier whispered, staring into the depths of his brother’s eyes. 

In that moment, the battlefield around them faded into insignificance. They were no longer soldiers fighting an unseen enemy but brothers grappling with the weight of a shared past they never knew existed.

Before they could fully comprehend the gravity of their reunion, gunfire erupted nearby, pulling them back into the reality of war. They exchanged a look filled with understanding, a silent agreement forged amidst the chaos. 

“Together,” the first Liam said, determination etched on his face.

“Always,” the other replied.

With unspoken trust, they moved as one; their instincts, honed from years of training, synchronized like a well-rehearsed dance. They fought side by side, their movements fluid, each knowing where the other would be, bridging the gap of years lost in silence.

As the last echoes of battle faded and the sun dipped low on the horizon, they found themselves standing amidst the wreckage, where brotherhood blossomed in the darkest of places. 

In the aftermath, as they slumped against the remnants of a wall, unscathed, they exchanged stories of their lives—of parents lost, of paths taken, and choices made. 

The war raged on around them, but they had found something indelible amid the destruction—an unbreakable bond. As night fell, they knew they would face whatever came next, hand in hand, two soldiers forged from the same fire.', 'The air was thick with smoke and the acrid scent of gunpowder as Sergeant James Holloway ducked behind a crumbling stone wall. Bullets whizzed past him like angry hornets, and the deafening roar of artillery filled his ears. The enemy was closing in, and hope was a distant thought.

He clenched his rifle tightly, his heart pounding not just from fear but from the weight of a promise he had made to his young daughter, Lily. Just a week prior, she had confided in him about her invisible friend, a whimsical creature who wore a starry cape and spoke in riddles. “He’ll always keep you safe, Daddy,” she had said, her bright eyes wide with conviction. James had chuckled softly, tucking her into bed, confident that such tales were the stuff of childhood imagination.

But in the chaos of war—where logic often falters—he found himself wishing for a miracle, however silly it might seem. 

Then, amidst the cacophony, a voice pierced the haze: “I am your child’s imaginary friend. They have sent me to protect you in your greatest time of need.”

James’s heart nearly stopped. The voice was soft and lilting, almost musical, with an otherworldly echo that seemed to meld with the sounds of battle. He looked around, bewildered. “What? Who said that?”

“Fear not, brave soldier,” the voice continued, now clearer, as if it were standing right beside him. “I can help you. Stay close, and trust in me.”

A flicker of movement caught his eye. James turned to see a shimmering figure taking form beside him—a small, ethereal being shrouded in clouds of stardust, its eyes twinkling like the night sky. It looked just like the description Lily had given, though he’d imagined it all to be a figment of her vivid imagination.

“Lily?” he whispered, half in disbelief.

“Yes, her heart sent me,” the creature replied, its voice soothing. “You are in danger, but together, we can turn the tide.”

The ground trembled as a bomb exploded nearby, sending debris flying. James felt a surge of adrenaline, the instinct of a soldier kicking in. “What do I do?” he shouted, unsure if he was talking to the apparition or himself.

“Follow my lead,” it urged, waving a tiny hand. “Move to the left. Now!”

With no time to ponder the strangeness of the situation, James followed the creature’s directions. He darted left, narrowly avoiding the burst of gunfire that erupted where he had been standing. His heart raced as he began to trust this inexplicable ally.

“Advance, Sergeant!” the voice guided him as they moved through the chaos, dodging bullets and obstacles. The creature was always a step ahead—a shield against the onslaught, a flicker of hope in the darkness.

With each successful dodge, a spark of faith ignited within him. Maybe this was not madness. Maybe magic existed.

Finally, they reached a vantage point overlooking the enemy’s position. James pointed his rifle, taking a breath to steady his aim. “What now?” he asked.

“Now,” it said, “you make history. For Lily.”

With a profound sense of purpose, he squeezed the trigger. The shot rang true, and the enemy fell back. One by one, his comrades rallied, following his lead.

As victory unfolded amid the chaos, the shimmering figure began to fade. “Remember, Sergeant, love and imagination are powerful forces. They will always guide you home.”

And just like that, it was gone. But James felt a warmth in his chest, an unbreakable bond connecting him to his daughter. With every heartbeat, he knew he would fight fiercely—both for his country and for the little girl who believed in magic.', "I was schooled at West Point Academy , the State of New York . I studied to be a brave officer who could lead men into battle and win them . That was ten-thousand years ago . I was one of the two highest graded students to ever pass the exam , the other was the woman I loved . We met on the first day of campus and we hit it off pretty quick , first as friends , then roommates , then lovers . Unusually we were both given the honor of Valedictorian , both speaking to all the other students at the graduation ceremony , which we used to announce our marriage as well as our plans for the future . We both went into the army shortly after , made our careers as during the Martian Revolution as tough but fair leaders . We were always fighting side by side , our divisions seeing us as parental figures that they would gladly fight with , our victories in putting down the uprising outshone most others . and when the Martian Liberation Army surrendered , they surrendered to us .     We became known as the Battle Couple , fighting together in unison to defend Earth and its many nations against whatever threat came . But when the Extermination War began , we took our forces to the stars , we did n't want to obey nations willing to exterminate entire cultures for the purpose of the establishment of the One Human State , something that many fought against . We wanted things to go on as they always had , but we were n't heard by the Unity Party of Terra that took over the planet . A quarter of the human race died at their hands , while about a fifth of the survivors fled Earth to reestablish their nations elsewhere . Sometimes I blame myself for not listening to her , we should have made a coup against the government , our troops were loyal enough to listen to us and we could have prevented the devastation .     Our forces instead went out to foreign alien worlds , trenched in war . Some on a higher scale of development than us , others lower , but it did n't matter , we sold our guns to the highest bidder , becoming the largest mercenary corps in the Milky Way Galaxy , as veterans from the Extermination War , the Martian Revolution and The Destruction of Earth joined our ranks as comrades in arms . We fought on a thousand worlds , me and my beloved , before she died . It was a mere chance , we had been hired to oversee the occupation and rebuilding of a proud warrior race 's planet after their utter defeat by a large coalition of races . A she was out at our infirmary , to cheer up the men , even after 60 years of war she looked like a Valkyrie , fierce , beautiful and dangerous . And when she was sitting at some soldiers bed , who had been wounded during a clash with a minor terrorist group , she was gunned down by insurgents .     They rushed her to the emergency room , and yet they could not save her . I flew in as fast as I could , and I barely managed to say goodbye . 60 years worth of battling , 40 since we started being mercenaries . And I saw her , frail , fragile and weak as I took her hand in mine , as I cried she told me , ''*Chin up dear , we knew it would end . I 'm sorry but I 'm going to go a bit before you 'll do . We 'll meet again in Valhalla . * '' She then fell back to sleep and never woke up . I left the planet with my army , after hunting down every last insurgent and executing them , personally . Not long after that , the Galactic Union of Peoples hired us to fight . A war had been brewing between them and the xenophobic madmen of the One Human State , they 'd been losing most battles due to the sheer tenacity of the human forces , and they wanted to try to bring in the only thing that can reasonably match a human being in ingenuity and daring , another human . In exchange for my army 's help they 'd allow the human states not under the One Human State admittance to the Union with all the tech and protection it gave them . And we would be granted the most advanced weaponry to use in battles .     I agreed . I wanted to go out in a blaze of glory to remember my beloved and maybe join her in Valhalla . And I wanted to know how human forces had defeated a vastly technologically superior army with far more numbers . The answer was droids . The entire army of the Galactic Union was made of lumbering machines rather than cunning bastards and warriors . Their commanders were non-sentient A.I . who were running projections and programs rather than battles . They lacked that spark of madness that makes a commander . So I sent in my forces , using the dumb automated droids as a distraction while I took the enemy from behind . It worked . They had expected another easily outwitted machine army , not the full force of a trained standing human army . After the battle the aliens asked me to be outfitted with a cloning safety until the war was over . I knew I could n't leave the war so I agreed . They put a thing in my brain that transferred my conscious mind to a cloned body so I could keep on fighting .     Over the years I helped them defeat the One Human State , and mankind got its vengeance for the total destruction of Earth that they had been responsible for . I was given the position of Absolute Commander of the Galactic Union for my aid , and having died several times during the war , I was young again . I used the title for all it was worth , trying to forget my love , to move on . Yet I could n't . All the fancy parties , the women and men , some not even humans . throwing themselves at me , the honor and the duty . I was somewhat hollow without her . The only times when I felt right was when I fought . I advocated military action whenever possible , sending in forces under my own command to pacify violent species , preventing extra-galactic incursion , ended interstellar piracy and I even once took over the government in a coup , ruling as the supreme leader of the galaxy for a century after the failures of the weak government to contain the peace between galactic abolitionists and slavers . I ended the Galactic Civil War and ended such vile practices permanently .     I stepped down from my position as head of the government , but de-facto and sometimes de-jure , I was the head of state for the entire galaxy . And after countless wars , countless possibilities , I still remember her . Her hair black as the raven , her eyes grey as the winter 's mist back on Earth . Her quick wit and sharp tongue , her determined wishes . Her utter faith in the gods of our common ancestors , she was a phenomenal woman , unlike any other through history . Ten-thousand years old , I am now . And I am fighting another war , another battle . But this one is different . Usually my vast experience in battles means that I can determine the movement of my foe before they know it , for over a dozen of centuries I have n't even had a casualty number higher than 50000 soldiers . Now I had lost half a million during a single battle .     Only she could ever outmaneuver me , only she had ever beat me . When we finally defeated their forces and went to demand the immediate surrender of the insurrectionist army , we were met with heavily entrenched lines and a nigh impregnable fortress . And there I saw her , moving towards me . Atop a black horse she rode , how she got one I do not know , but it looks dramatic . She rides to met me in the No-Man 's Land that separates our forces . She looked at me with such a strange look in her face , recognition , sadness and to my surprise , fear .     ''*I thought you dead . * '' She said , her voice like a violin , her gaze like thunder .     ''*I saw you die . I kept on fighting . * ''     ''*You never knew when to stop , did you ? It was always me that held you back . And now you 've become an undying warrior , eternally fighting . I waited in Valhalla until someone called me back . These people you are fighting , do you even know how they see you ? * ''     ''*As the evil hand of the government or an oppressor I imagine . * ''     She laughed , like she always did whenever I said something inherently wrong . It was like the memories of my life came swirling back , every minute we spent together , our children , our homes . Our playful games and our many travels across the galaxy . It was intoxicating .     ''*No my love , you are a god to them . The eternal god of war , when I woke I spoke with people over the Galacnet , went to Reddit and saw the stories of you there , some see you as Odin incarnated into the mortal realm , others call you Amarok , the Wolf , some name you as the living god-incarnate of Huitzilopochtli and claim that this world was made by you . You are feared by all , understood by none . Why do you think they brought me back ? To defeat you once and for all . * ''     ''*I have brought peace . Have I not ? * ''     ''*At what cost ? You live for the war , and see not the real world . Temples rise for you , aliens worship you openly , none of them dare to speak to you though . They brought me back because their faith sees you as an mad incarnation of their own deity , a version driven mad by the loss of his beloved . I fill that role . Please , you have lived for so long now , wont you come with me at long last to Valhalla ? * ''     ''*I can not leave before the battle is over . End it , and I 'll join you . * ''     ''*My pleasure . * ''     She came up to me , embraced me , and sent an electric shock through my body . I stumbled back , confused and disorientated from the shock .     ''*What did you do ! * ''     ''*Easy . I destroyed the implant in you , my love . It ends now . Together we 'll die , the truth is that we must end . All things must end or else they will have not been worth living for . * ''     With those words she charged with a blade , stabbing me through the chest , missing the heart by a few centimeters . My men then gunned her down , killing her . And as I lie here , bleeding , visions of things I see . A great castle where a smiling woman comes running at me with a loving smile . She is my beloved , she is the woman I have always fought by and loved . I see her face clearly , and all is now done . Faint voices and screams echo in my ears , yet they are but memories of the past . I let go and run forwards to embrace her . I am home , at long last ."]

Name: 6_death_of_to_my
Representative_Docs:
["There 's a man who dwells in a cave on the top of the Himalayas . They said he 's the strongest of us all , with unimaginable god like powers . I 've always heard stories of him growing up , the older folks talked about him like he was savior . They said the world would n't have been here had it not for him . But the laws of nature dictates that our powers comes with a balance , a balance for our mind . Many powerful ones died before their time due to this . And those who survived often became hermits . If the legend holds true , there are good reasons for this man to hid himself worlds away . However , that will not stop me from finding him . After all , that is my power . I can find anything , the forgotten and the hidden . But I can not place my own past , and I need to find my own past . The scars and the name tattooed on my body hints at my past everyday . Now my curiosity has got the best of me and I have to know .     For days now I 've been hiking up the Himalaya mountains , I know where he is , I can feel him in my guts . But the path is treacherous , he 's chosen his hideout wisely . With every step I take towards , I found out more about him . His emotions became clearer , they are powerful and volatile . It 's like a dragon being contained inside a small box that could barely fit a cat . It must have taken all his will to withhold his instincts , whatever that may be .     He 's sensed me , I can feel that now . It must have been because of last night when I lost a toe to frostbite . He did n't seem to care though .     At last I 've made it after three weeks journey . This trip has taken all my strength and stamina . Perhaps it 's too late to think about how to get back down . It does n't matter now , I need to know who I am . I look around and noticed how calm and quiet it is here . No snow or storm , and not a single living creature or greens in sight by the concave . I wondered what he lived on , has his powers made him immortal ?     `` Seeker ... '' A powerfully loud voice came from the cave . Not the rusty old voice I had imagined . `` You came for nothing . ''     I walked into the dark cave , as confident as I could . I figure I 'm already here , there 's no point in turning back now or doubt myself . I want to see this man , this legend .     Average . That 's what crossed my mind when I saw him . Average height , early 40s , a bit chubby , receding hairline , glasses . He looks like my accountant .     `` They said you 're the most powerful of us all . Did I came to the right place ? ''     `` That 's not the question you want to ask . I ca n't help you . '' He said , without taking his eyes off the book he 's holding . A blank book , at least I know he 's nuts .     `` You mean you wo n't help me . '' I decide to provoke him and see what happens . `` Or are you really just a myth , a hermit with no powers . ''     `` Go back to your life and live out the remaining years this world has to offer you . '' He looks at me with a blank stare . `` I ca n't just give you a past , it 's complicated . This world is not perfect and I 'm too tired . ''     `` Give me a past ? No , I just want to remember . ''     `` Inventing , remembering , it 's all the same from my point of view . It would be easier to destroy the world than to fix all the little details . ''     `` What ? What do you mean ? You can destroy the world ? You are mad ! ''     `` You do n't get it , it 's because the world is my creation . It 's all in my head . '' His stares tell me he 's serious , this is one hell of a nutjob , and I lost a toe for this ?     `` Yea ? Show me then , show me your powers ! ''     He kept his stares and then he sighs . `` Ok , I guess it 's going to happen sooner or later . ''     In a blink he was gone .     I look outside and saw the sky falling apart , like old dry paint coming off a wall . It 's amazing , I wish there 's someone I can tell this story to , but I guess the whole world knows about the end at this moment .  ", 'The Immortal's Dilemma

For centuries, I had walked this earth, my steps echoing through the ages. Death, my only companion, had granted me the curse of immortality, binding us together in an eternal dance of life and demise.

In the beginning, I resented my newfound longevity, watching helplessly as my loved ones withered and faded, while I remained unchanged. But as the years passed, I came to cherish the gift – or was it a curse? – that had been bestowed upon me. With an eternity stretching before me, I dedicated myself to the betterment of humanity, determined to create a world where Death would have less work to do.

I traveled the globe, using my boundless knowledge and resources to combat war, disease, and poverty. I funded medical research, brokered peace treaties, and championed humanitarian causes. All the while, I kept a watchful eye on my old friend, Death, hoping to catch a glimpse of him, to steal a moment of his precious time.

But Death, it seemed, was always busy. As I watched the centuries unfold, the toll of human suffering weighed heavily on my soul. I saw empires rise and fall, civilizations crumble, and new ones emerge, each leaving its mark on the world. And through it all, Death remained elusive, his scythe ever-swinging, his work never-ending.

Centuries passed, and I found myself growing weary, my once-boundless energy waning. I had achieved so much, yet it felt hollow without the companionship of my old friend. I longed for the days when we would sit together, sharing stories and contemplating the mysteries of the universe.

One day, as I wandered the streets of a bustling metropolis, I caught a glimpse of a familiar figure in the distance. It was Death, his dark cloak billowing in the wind, his skeletal face hidden in the shadows. Without hesitation, I gave chase, determined not to lose him this time.

I followed him through the crowded streets, weaving between pedestrians and dodging traffic, until finally, he led me to a quiet park, where he stood waiting, his gaze fixed on the horizon.

"I've been expecting you," he said, his voice a whisper on the wind.

"I've missed you, old friend," I replied, my voice heavy with emotion.

Death turned to face me, his empty sockets seemingly filled with a profound sadness. "I know," he said. "But my work never ends, and I cannot afford to linger. There is always another soul to reap, another life to claim."

I nodded, understanding the weight of his burden. "Then let me help you," I said. "Let me use my immortality to ease your task, to create a world where you can rest, even if for a moment."

Death considered my offer, his bony fingers tapping thoughtfully against his scythe. "Very well," he said at last. "But be warned, the path you have chosen is a difficult one, fraught with countless challenges and heartaches. Are you prepared to bear that burden?"

I looked into the empty sockets of Death's face, and in that moment, I knew my answer. "I am," I said, my voice filled with determination. "For you are my only friend, and I will do whatever it takes to walk by your side once more."

And so, with a solemn nod, Death and I set forth, our eternal partnership renewed, our sights set on a future where peace and harmony reigned supreme.', "For the past 10 years I 've roamed the earth as a ghost . It 's lonely at times but you get used to it . When your dead you have the chance to do one last thing before you either go to Heaven or Hell . In my case it was hell . I could have went to Hell a long time ago but I decided to stick around . A lot of us lost souls do . Too afraid to let go of our old lives that we stick around as long as we can but being stuck in limbo is not fun . It is n't meant to be . The days go by very slow . It feels slow because you ca n't actually do anything . You can only observe . You only have the ability to do something when you 've decided to go to your `` final destination '' .     I decided it was time for me to leave the world of the living . I knew Hell was waiting for me but I could n't imagine it was much worse then this . Just minutes going by so slow unable to act on any of the urges you feel . It 's torture .     In order to do your unfinished business you had to pick a host . I decided to pick my son . I did n't care much for him when he was a child , I did n't care much for anyone really . I did however stayed with him during these past 10 years . Watching him . Wondering how someone like me could have such an amazing child . He was . I 'm not sentimental but he was amazing . He was tall , handsome , funny and most of all brilliant . His mind was like no other . He could charm the panties of a Nun . Something I know he got from me .     I died when my son was 10 . I left before he was born . So I never got to meet him . I left his mother because she was unattractive , dumb and very clingy . I basically used her for a place to stay . She did n't ask much of me . She did want sex occasionally and with enough liquor the sex was n't half bad . Problem was I got so drunk I almost never got a condom on . So she got pregnant . I was so upset and I wanted to kill but killing her would give me no thrill . She was pathetic and killing someone that pathetic is like killing a puppy . There is no reason to .     I liked killing blonde hair little girls and their mothers . It was fun for me . I had only killed three mothers and 2 daughters . The third mother I had killed had a 9 year old little girl . I tried to be real quiet while breaking in but I had made some noise and the mother came running downstairs . I knew I had to attack . It was going to be sloppy and I did n't care for sloppy but I could n't leave her alive to tell on me . Normally I 'd tip toe into their room and inject a needle loaded with a heavy sedative so that they could stay asleep . Then I would proceed with the slicing and dicing .     When the mother came flying down the stairs I knew I was made . I decided to just lunge at her . She put up a fight . In all of the commotion I did n't even bother to think of the little girl . Only that I needed to end this lady and leave as fast as I could . During our scuffle I managed to fall down just close enough to the fire place that I could grab a poker and swing it into this lady 's skull . She was out . I removed the poker from her head and kept swinging and swinging it at her . She was done but I was n't .     I had enough time left over so I decided to go into the little girls room . When I peaked in she was n't on her bed . She managed to escape from her bedroom window . She probably ran for help so I knew I needed to bail before she got back with the police .     I got into my car and hauled ass out of that street . I was driving so fast I drove the a red light . It was bad timing because a truck coming from my drivers side hit me . I was killed instantly . So there I was dead . A cliche white light appeared and although I could hear nothing verbally or see anything there was now an knowledge I now had . I knew where I was meant to go to Hell but I could stay for one last unfinished business and that when I decided to do it I 'd had to pick a host . I now understood this so I decided to stick around and watch my son grow up until I decided when and what my unfinished business was .     Today was going to be it . I watched my son sleep peacefully . I did n't know how taking over his body might affect him so I decided to just do while he was asleep . It was hard really . I just said to myself `` Put me in his body . '' When I blinked I was now inside my son . I could feel all of my senses heightened but times a million . It felt like nothing I 've ever felt before . I did n't know if it because I was a ghost and had some type of extra senses or because I had n't touched , smell , or hear anything for 10 years . It did n't matter . I was free .     My unfinished business I had decided would be to kill the little girl I did n't kill 10 years ago . I had scoped her out for a few weeks prior mainly to work and school . She had a routine and I wanted to capitalize on that . I decided to `` run into her '' at school . Since my son also attended that college I figured it would be easy enough . My son was handsome and charming I just had to turn up the charm and hopefully get in good with her .     So I waited outside of her class room . I did n't want to do anything cheesy so I decided I would just ask her out . To my surprise she said yes . I knew my son had it but I figured she would at least make me/him work for it . She kissed me on the cheek and said she would call me later .     I thought it was strange she said she would call me later I did n't give her my/my sons number . I did n't give it much more thought . I pulled my cell phone from my pants . Looked at it trying to figure out how it worked and waited until she called .     She called around 10pm . When she called I answered real sweet . `` You called ! '' She did n't sound as happy . All she said was `` Dennis I love you . Thank you for giving me the best few weeks of my life but you ca n't save me . I know you tried but I just ca n't do this anymore . '' Her voice was strong . She sounded as if she was just a second away from losing all composure . I was n't sure what to say . I just replied `` Then do n't do it anymore . But whatever it is we can figure it out . Can we meet up to talk ? '' She paused . I waited anxiously. `` Yeah . Can you be here in about two hours ? I 'll leave the door unlocked just let yourself in . '' She hangs up . She does n't even say goodbye . I did n't care I was over the moon . Man this was so much easier than I thought . She basically invited me to kill her ! I had planned this out quite carefully . I did n't want my son to be blamed for this murder so I planned this long and hard .     When I arrived to her house I let myself in . I called out her name but no reply . I looked around and their were pictures of her mother everywhere . It was like a museum of this women . When I finally made my way to the kitchen without seeing this girl I decided to make my way upstairs . There were 4 doors on this floor but only one with a light on . I opened it up slowly and when I finally opened it all the way i was shocked to see her hanging from her ceiling . She had killed herself . A note lied on the bed . It reads .     `` Dennis ,     When I met you in group therapy I thought we 'd have nothing in common . I know we had two absent parents but my mother was brutally killed and your father just left you . How could you know my pain . You somehow convinced me you did and that I was stronger then my pain but I 'm not . The ghost of my mother still haunts me . I can still hear her screams . I just want to make it all go away . I want to be with her finally . I miss her so much . I hope you can forgive me for doing this to you but I just ca n't looking to you to keep me planted in reality . Thank you for giving me the best last months of my life . Take care and do good things ''     Before I could even process my thoughts I was instantly removed from my sons body . I now stood next to him as he discovered his girlfriend hanging from the ceiling . He screams and frantically tries to get her down . He calls 911 . I know I only have one chance at unfinished business and if it fails then you are sent directly to Heaven or Hell . I knew I had to go to Hell . In all this time I did n't feel liked I deserved to go to Hell . I mean I knew I had to but I did n't feel bad for my crimes until now . I may be going to Hell but now I forced my son to live it on earth . I 'm instantly sucked out of this world and thrown straight into the pits .     It was a hot jail like cell . I had no bed , no toilet . Just a tv . The TV was set to the scene of my son outside talking to police explaining how he must have arranged to meet her here and walked in on her hanging . He had the text to prove it and would n't get in trouble but now I had to watch my amazing , handsome , funny smart son destroy his life . Destroy everything . There was no good in me but I was happy knowing there was a lot of good in him .     For the rest of my sons life I watched him tear his life apart in the worst ways . Had you asked me if my son would go to Heaven or Hell when he died my money would be on the big beautiful place in the sky . Instead years later my son now sits next to me as we watch all the rest of the lives we both destroyed .  "]

Name: 7_president_the_of_to
Representative_Docs: ["This is going to sound crazy .     Seriously . I know this will sound totally stupid , but just hear me out . I swear it will make sense by the end . And if it does n't ? Well , shoot me then , I guess . But I 'm running out of time , so I 'd better hurry this up .     So , anyway , do you remember three years ago , when someone tried to shoot the President ? Of course , he was n't the President then , he was n't even the nominee . Hell , no-one even thought he was * gon na * be the nominee . Two weeks before Super Tuesday , trailing the two leading candidates by eighteen points ? Wittering on about terrorism , and no-one was buying it . Well , that changed in a hurry after he got shot . The election was barely even a contest .     I did that . I mean , I did n't *mean* to , but I did . I was n't even aiming at him anyway . It was his wife . His wife . God ... she was always so beautiful .     We met at college , you see . The only woman I ever loved . And boy did I love her . I never really got over her . I heard she got married , and it sucked . I did n't sleep for a week . Before I met her , I never realized that `` heartache '' was literal .     The pain went away over time , mostly . I mean , if I thought about her , I did n't cry , I did n't cut myself . I could deal . Until her ass-wipe husband starts running for President . All the media knew he was a jack-ass , but she ... she was made for the campaign trail .     I could n't get away from it . She was everywhere . I 'd turn on the TV , or try to get a magazine , or just fucking drive down the street , and she 'd be there . Smiling . Watching . Staring at me from the news-stands and the billboards . And it hurt .     And one day , I just snapped I guess . I ca n't even really explain what happened . I just could n't fucking take it any more . I could n't deal with it . It hurt too damn much . So ... I bought myself a rifle . I do n't have it any more - threw it in the river the next morning just in case - but I remember it . It felt so good in my hands . A kind of reassuring weight , like how her child would 've felt in my arms .     It was surprisingly easy after that . I 'd always been a good shoot , but I practiced . Walked into a hotel room with a guitar case like something in the movies . Almost no-one even looked at me . I thought it was a good day .     But I missed . Of fucking course I did . Hit her asshole husband in the shoulder . Suddenly , he went from being a looney-toon spouting on about terrorists to being a visionary who 'd shed blood for his point .     Honestly , I thought they 'd catch me , but no-one even questioned me . I wonder if he pulled some strings , so that no-one was looking for me . It kept festering in my head . It would n't fit his rhetoric if he was shot by a pathetic little white-boy who never got over a summer fling with the President Elect 's wife .     I could n't get over that thought . It ate at me , until that 's all I could think of myself . Pathetic little white-boy . Ca n't even fucking shoot straight .     That 's when I really lost it . I just started trying to kill people after that . The first one was to prove it to myself ... I was gon na kill someone . Anyone . I did n't even care about getting caught . I just wanted to prove I could do it .     I chose her because she was kind of pretty , and looked a little like ... like her . I was gon na shoot her and her boyfriend . Went with the boyfriend first , and she ran off the second he went down . I read later that he was her step-dad , and he 'd been molesting her .     `` I do n't know who killed him , but he freed me '' . I was n't sure if I should laugh or cry .     The next one was just someone I met at a mall . Reach out , a bit of a push , and watch them tumble down the stairs . Two weeks later , he 'd had some experimental medical procedure that finally got rid of his back pain , and a cheque from the mall owner . He could finally set up the gym he 'd always dreamed about . Good for him , I guess .     The bomb did n't work . I 'd had a fight with the cops over a parking ticket , so I tried to bomb the station . The same bastard who 'd ticketed me found it , and now he 's a hero . Of course , the President himself took an interest in that one , and cops got more powers . I never thought I 'd see the day they 'd put CCTV cameras on every single street .     I ca n't even remember most of the rest . I tried to set my land-lady 's house on fire while she slept . I did n't even hate her - she was just close by . Of course , she woke up half-way . New house , insurance pay-out , and some deal with the electrics company for faulty wiring . Then , there was the time I crashed my car . Literally , just drove through a red and straight into another car . Husband died - wife-beater . Apparently , he was such an evil fucker that the wife and the cops just let me off . Hell , she hugged me , and said thank you .     Twenty-four people in total . I tried to kill twenty four different people , and every single time , it only made them happier . It 's like I have a gift - if I try to kill someone , their life gets better .     Twenty-five was always my lucky number . That 's why I 'm doing this now . If you 're reading this , cut me down . I just want something good to happen to me now .     I mean , what 's the worst that can happen - right ?", "**I totally misread the prompt but I 'm gon na post it anyways . **       The newly elected president stood behind the podium . Before him stood a sea of cheering Americans . On each side of him was a pane of bulletproof glass . He confidently tugged at his tie . It was a dark blue tie with a full windsor knot . The President leaned forward towards the mic slowly , glancing around the crowd with a smile as he did . He drew in a deep breath and opened his mouth to begin his speech .     But before he could say a single word , he was interrupted by very loud , deep , popping noises that shook that ground on which he stood . These sounds were followed by the sounds of screaming . Screams of agony and screams of fear . Plumes of smoke rose out among a sea of scrambling people .     The Secret Service agents surrounded the President , each facing outwards . `` Sir we have to leave now . Everyone stick together ! '' As the circle of agents began to move backwards towards the Capitol , something caught the President 's eye . It was a man in a mask .     The President knew that this was his moment of truth . He needed to show the country he was a true leader . A true leader should be fearless . The President knew what he had to do . He raised his arms in the air . The secret service agents looked at him bewildered . `` Mr. President you have to stay low ! '' The President seemed oblivious to the advice of his protectors . His eyes had glazed over and his mind was on another plane .     `` All right , time 's up , let 's do this . '' the President said calmly . The President then broke through the wall of agents surrounding him and leaped off of the platform and into the crowd below while shouting his name . `` LEEEEEEEEERRRRRRRROOOOOOOOOOOYYYYYY JEEENNNNKIINNNSS ! ''     `` Mr. President no ! '' Shouted the lead agent chasing after him . The lead agent shouted to the others , `` Follow me ! Stick together ! Get to the President , form a perimeter , STICK TO THE PLAN ! ! ! ''     The President cut through the crowd making a bee-line for the man in the mask . As he got closer to the man in the mask , more men in masks began to appear in front of him . Soon there were more than he could count . He was surrounded . The masked men charged at the President .     One of the masked men tackled the President to the ground . The man then stood up , grabbed the President by his tie , and began to drag him through the mud into the group of masked men . The masked men began to kick and beat the President mercilessly . The President 's body soon went limp , unable to resist anymore . When he stopped resisting , the masked men took a few steps away from the President , still surrounding him . One of the masked men stepped forward . The man kneeled down and lifted up his pant-leg , revealing a very large combat knife . He grabbed the President by his hair and lifted up the President 's head . The kneeling man looked the President in the eyes . The President could n't see the masked man 's mouth but he knew the man was smiling from the squint of his eyes behind the mask . The smiling masked man thrust the knife into the President 's side .     Just as the knife was plunged into the President , the Secret Service agents sprang out of a nearby crowd and began rushing towards the masked men . The President lay on the ground , his suit torn , covered in mud and bruises . The knife remained in his side and around it was a pool of red . Half-conscious , the president slowly lifted his head up from the mud to look at his agents . They were overwhelmed by the masked men . There were too many of them . One by one the agents fell .     The President knew that this was it . This was the end . He turned his gaze away from the sight of his falling agents . It was too much to bear . When he turned his head he felt something on the ground next to him . He looked . It was a paper bucket lying on its side . He reached for the bucket to turn the opening towards him . Slowly he managed to swivel the bucket so that he could look inside . The bucket contained fried chicken . Drumsticks to be exact . His favorite food . The President reached in and used his remaining strength to enjoy what he knew was his last meal .     The head secret service lay on the ground , his legs shattered by the ruthless stomping of the masked men . He was about ten feet away from the President . He used his arms to crawl towards the President . The adrenaline rush still masked the pain from his shattered bones . He got within three feet of the President before he could move no further . He turned his face towards the President , squinting . The President looked back at him , still lying on the ground covered in mud , but with a drumstick in his hand . The President appeared to be chewing . The agent sighed , `` God dammit Leroy . '' The agent 's head dropped into the mud face down .     `` At least I have chicken , '' replied the President .", "Arthur buried his head in his hands . They were rough and wrinkled from years of toil outdoors . Once , a lifetime ago , Arthur Bundirn had been a farmer .     Now , from his office the fate of the free world was decided . At least , that 's what the mob outside the White House gates believed . The media sold it as God 's own truth that the President was the one to blame for the current crisis .     Arthur could n't begin to explain just how powerless he felt .     Chanting could be heard , even through the reinforced walls of the West Wing . There were four buildings on fire around Lafayette Square , where the peaceful demonstration had become a riot . Three dozen well-armed marines and a wrought-iron fence were all that stood between the President and his nation 's fury .     Arthur wondered if the marines hated him , too .     He supposed they must .     `` I need to speak to them . '' The President said and looked up , his eyes were wet and red .     `` They wo n't listen . '' Mark replied . He paced nervously back and forth on the other side of the President 's desk .     `` They lost their jobs when the recession hit . '' Mark continued . `` Then , Yellowstone was enough to cause mass panic . They 're crazed , unwilling to hear reason . ''     `` Do n't I know it . '' The President sighed .     He turned in his chair and stared out the window . The White House fountain was choked with soot . The trees wore ash like it was new fashion . The sky was dark and brooding .     The ash still fell , like stained snowflakes , and darkened everything it touched .     *How could I have known ? * Arthur wondered . *What could I have done ? *     America was starving . Fourteen days of continuous eruption had cast enough material into the sky to blacken it for months . The crops had died . The rivers ran dark and toxic with debris .     Hospitals were full to the brim with asthmatic patients .     The President did n't know what to do . The most powerful nation in the world had been brought to its knees in just shy of a single year . Besides food aid , there was little the rest of the world could , or wanted , to do to help .     Some nations , like China and Russia had revved up their war machines , correctly guessing that the United States ' counterbalancing force was now preoccupied . Five separate wars were being fought on various scales in Europe and Asia . And to think , there was a President who had run on the idea that it was time to move past strong-arm diplomacy . The media loved to run that clip on repeat .     The sad part was , Arthur still believed it .     The sharp stacatto of gunfire met the President 's ears . The mob 's chanting became a roar . It was as if some multi-mouthed monstrosity had come to gobble him up . Several other guns joined into a symphony .     The Oval Office 's door burst open .     `` Mr. President , they 've begun climbing the fence . '' A secret service agent said , his voice unnervingly calm . `` You and the Chief of Staff need to get into the bunker now . ''     `` I need to speak to them . '' Arthur said , softly .     `` Mr. President , if they want you dead , there 's no way we can stop them . '' The agent commandingly .     The President nodded .     Then , Arthur stood and straightened his tie . He wondered briefly whether he should have ever left Ohio . If he had n't , he supposed , he might well be in that same crowd outside .     `` I have one last speech to give . '' He said .     Neither of the other two heard him . The sound of glass shattering suddenly increased the pitch of the roar to new heights . A scream of terror sounded somewhere in the building .     `` They 're inside . '' The agent said and drew his gun .     `` One nation , under God , indivisible ... '' The President began his final speech ."]

Name: 8_clara_her_she_the
Representative_Docs:
["In an unremarkable town, nestled between rolling hills and a placid river, lived a woman named Clara. Her days were filled with the mundane routines of life—waking up at dawn, tending to her garden, making bread, and volunteering at the local library. The townspeople adored her. Clara’s laughter was like melody, her kindness a warm blanket that wrapped around everyone who crossed her path.

Years slipped by, and Clara never thought much of her existence, content in the simplicity of her life. It wasn't until her seventieth birthday that a strange sense of inevitability washed over her. She had spent her life as a caretaker, a listener, a friend. But, as the sun dipped below the horizon that fateful evening, something deep within her began to stir.

The next morning, Clara didn’t wake to the sound of chirping birds or the smell of freshly baked bread. Instead, she found herself in a brilliant white expanse, suspended in an ethereal calm. It felt like a dream, yet the sensation of reality was sharper than the sharpest knife.

As she stood there, a figure approached—a luminous silhouette that radiated warmth and love. It was neither man nor woman but an embodiment of pure energy, and with every step, Clara felt a sense of peace engulf her.

“Welcome, Clara.” The figure’s voice resonated like soft chimes. “You are here to see your task.”

Clara’s heart raced. “My task? What was it?”

The figure waved an arm, and visions flickered to life around them like paintings in an invisible gallery. Clara watched scenes from her life unfold—her first day of volunteering at the library, when she helped a timid child find courage to read aloud. Her laughter echoing as she collaborated with the town’s youth on a gardening project, teaching them the beauty of patience and care.

Then it shifted—the images grew darker, as she saw moments of pain. A grieving widow who sat quietly in the corner of the library, finding solace in Clara’s presence. A young man, lost and struggling, who found hope in Clara’s words of encouragement. Life and death intertwined, joy and sorrow blended, all illuminated by her simple acts of kindness.

“You were a beacon,” the figure explained. “Your task was to be the thread that connects hearts. Each small kindness was a stitch in the fabric of humanity, weaving together lives that would otherwise remain frayed and isolated.”

Clara felt a swell of emotion. She had never thought of herself in such grand terms. “But I was just… me.”

“Precisely. You were simply you.” The figure smiled. “In a world where many are lost, your light guided souls through their darkest passages. You were a keeper of hope.”

As the visions faded, an overwhelming sense of fulfillment washed over Clara. She understood now that her existence, though seemingly ordinary, had rippled through the lives of countless individuals, leaving behind a legacy of compassion and connection.

“Thank you,” she whispered, tears of joy streaming down her face as she felt the warmth of the figure envelop her. “Thank you for letting me understand.”

And with that, Clara’s heart fluttered, and she was ready to return. Back to the garden, the library, the laughter, and the love. She had fulfilled her purpose, and it was more profound than she could ever have imagined.", 'The rain drummed a steady rhythm against the window, a symphony that matched the melancholy in Clara’s heart. She sat curled up on her old, threadbare couch, the flickering candlelight casting shadows that danced like lost souls across her cluttered living room. At twenty-eight, she felt the weight of loneliness more than ever. Friends had gotten married, started families, while she was still hoping to find someone with whom to share her life’s journey. 

That evening, as she stared into her lukewarm cup of tea, Clara whispered a prayer to the heavens, her voice barely above a whisper. “God, if you’re listening, please grant me one wish: let me find love before I die.” 

She sighed, her breath fogging the glass window. “I don’t need much,” she added, her heart heavy. “Just someone to hold, someone to love me.”

With that, she closed her eyes and let sleep take her.

Days turned into weeks, and the rain fell endlessly. Clara went through the motions of life, but something was off. She felt a peculiar energy coursing through her, something vibrant and alive. She brushed it off, attributing it to an overactive imagination born of boredom. But as she stepped outside to breathe in the post-rain scent of fresh earth, she noticed something odd—a reflection in the store window.

Her own face looked unchanged, yet there was an unmistakable glint in her eyes. She shook her head, convinced it was a trick of the light. But the feeling lingered, as if she had awakened from a long slumber.

Months passed, seasons shifted, and still, the feeling remained. Clara found herself untouched by the passage of time, her peers aging while she stood still. It wasn’t until her thirtieth birthday that she realized—she was immortal.

At first, she reveled in the thought. No more fears of growing old alone, she could take her time finding love. But as years added to decades, and decades stretched into centuries, the thrill faded. She watched as friends faded into memories, their laughter echoing in her mind like ghosts. She dated—oh, how she dated—but none sparked the connection she craved. It was as if they sensed her timelessness and ran from her, leaving her to wander through the corridors of the eternal.

One evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon, Clara sat on a park bench, her heart heavy with despair. “I didn’t mean this,” she whispered to the stars. “I wanted a partner, not an eternity of solitude.”

Just as she closed her eyes, prepared to sulk in her thoughts, a warm voice interrupted her solitude. “Do you mind if I join you?”

Clara opened her eyes to find a man standing there, his smile lighting up the dusk. Something in his gaze felt familiar, an echo of her own longing mirrored back at her. 

“I’m Evan,” he introduced himself, and Clara felt a spark, a connection that had eluded her for so long.

As they talked and laughter filled the air, Clara realized something profound. Immortality wasn’t just about endless days; it was about the endless possibilities of connection. With newfound hope, she understood that love might come when she least expected it. And in that moment, she felt grateful—not just for the gift of eternity, but for the chance to finally share it.', "The air was crisp, the kind of cold that wrapped around you like a warm embrace, as Clara sat on the edge of a familiar lake. The surface shimmered with the reflection of stars, and she felt a gentle pull, as if the water had secrets to share. Tonight, Clara would finally understand.

A soft rustling in the trees broke her reverie, and a figure emerged from the shadows. It was her grandmother, a shimmering silhouette against the night sky, the warmth of her smile easing Clara's anxiety. 

“Hello, my dear,” her grandmother said, the soft lilt of her voice echoing softly in the stillness. “You’re ready, aren’t you?”

Clara nodded, her heart pounding. She had lived an ordinary life—one filled with moments of joy and pain, love lost and love found. But as she approached the end of her journey, she often wondered what her purpose had truly been. The world had whispered secrets throughout her life, but she longed for clarity.

With a wave of her hand, her grandmother gestured for her to stand. “Let’s go,” she said. The air shimmered, and Clara felt a gentle tug, as if the world itself was pulling her into a new reality.

In an instant, they stood in a grand hall, its walls adorned with a mosaic of memories. Each tile glowed softly as they passed, illuminating scenes from Clara’s life—her first steps, her mother’s laughter, the countless nights spent alone in her small apartment, sketching dreams into existence. Everything felt deeply familiar yet eternally distant.

“Those moments were yours to experience,” her grandmother explained, “but they are mere stepping stones. Follow me.”

They reached a massive door, ancient and ornate. Clara’s heart raced as her grandmother pushed it open with an effortless grace. A vast expanse unfolded before them, a canvas of colors interwoven with threads of light. Clara gasped as she recognized forms dancing in the distance—people she had known and loved, each connected by invisible threads.

“This is the tapestry of life,” her grandmother said, her voice filled with reverence. “Every soul is woven intricately, each thread vital. You were not just a spectator, Clara. You were a weaver.”

Confusion flickered in Clara’s eyes. “A weaver? But how?”

Her grandmother smiled gently. “Each kindness you showed, every moment of understanding, they were threads you spun into the lives of others. Your laughter brightened the darkest days, and your compassion comforted hearts in distress. You may not have built monuments or changed the world in an overt way, but your quiet strength has rippled through the lives of those around you.”

As the realization washed over her, Clara felt warmth spread through her being. Each connection she had fostered, every silent prayer she had whispered for the lost, had created a web of light that bound them all together. 

“Now you can see,” her grandmother said softly. “Your part in the master plan was not about grand gestures, but about the simple truth that love begets love. Your legacy is the light you ignited in others.”

Clara felt tears spring to her eyes as she turned back to the hall, the vibrant tapestry shimmering with life. At that moment, she realized that she had truly lived, and it was enough. In her heart, she carried the stories of countless lives, woven together by hope, laughter, and love. She was a part of something beautiful, a song sung softly in the chorus of existence.

And just like that, Clara stepped forward, ready to embrace the next chapter of her journey."]

Name: 9_power_my_to_powers
Representative_Docs:
["The Day I Turned Sixteen

I remember the day I turned sixteen like it was yesterday. The anticipation and excitement were palpable as my friends and I eagerly awaited the moment we would discover our newfound abilities. 

Every person in the world was bestowed with a unique power or mutation on their sixteenth birthday. Some were more remarkable than others, but we all shared the same sense of wonder and curiosity.

As the clock struck midnight, the transformations began. My best friend, Emily, suddenly found herself able to levitate small objects with her mind. Another friend, Lucas, could control the weather, conjuring rain or sunshine at will. 

I watched in awe as each of my friends unveiled their special talents, marveling at the incredible display of human potential. But as the hours ticked by, I remained unchanged, waiting in anticipation for my own power to manifest.

As the day wore on, the excitement gave way to confusion and concern. Why hadn't my ability surfaced? Was I the only one left without a power? The uncertainty weighed heavily on me, and I couldn't help but feel left out.

Finally, as the sun began to set, I felt a strange sensation coursing through my body. Suddenly, everything around me slowed to a crawl, and I could see the world in a new, mesmerizing way. I realized that I had the power to manipulate time itself.

At first, I was thrilled, reveling in the ability to slow down or speed up the world around me. I could catch a falling vase before it shattered, or watch a bird in flight for what seemed like an eternity.

But as I experimented with my power, I began to understand the true gravity of my ability. I could not only slow or stop time, but I could also rewind it. The implications were staggering – I could undo mistakes, change the course of events, and even prevent tragedies.

The burden of this power weighed heavily on me. I knew that with great power came great responsibility, and I struggled to come to terms with the immense responsibility that had been thrust upon me.

As I grew older, I learned to navigate the complexities of my ability, using it to help others and make the world a better place. But the knowledge that I could alter the fabric of reality, to change the past and shape the future, was a constant source of anxiety and introspection.

In the end, I realized that my power was a double-edged sword – a gift and a curse that would forever shape the course of my life. But I vowed to use it wisely, to make a difference, and to never take for granted the incredible power that had been entrusted to me.", "The world found out about my powers not too long after I graduated from high school , when I saved that kid on the subway tracks , but I found out right around puberty . Or maybe I first gained my ability when I went through puberty , I don ’ t know . I definitely associate it with puberty though , because … well , because of the type of things I used my power for . Let ’ s just say that when a middle school boy discovers that he can stop time , he looks at a lot of boobs . SO many boobs .     I didn ’ t tell anyone . Not even my friends . I remember later spending a lot of time in high school worrying about all the good that I could be doing but was instead neglecting , just to hide my dirty secret . I couldn ’ t do anything that might let people know what I could do , maybe someone would remember some of those strange things that had happened around town , and they ’ d put two and two together .     But then I graduated and moved away , and I relaxed a bit . When I just impulsively stopped time to pull that kid away from the subway train , it felt so good to finally use my power the right way ( not to mention all the praise and awe I received ) . I decided that was my chance to really dedicate myself to helping people . I just hoped it would atone for some of the things I had done .     At first I tried to stay vague about my power , and just let people assume I was super fast , or that I could teleport . I didn ’ t like the idea of people realizing what all I could do . But as it turns out , reporters don ’ t typically settle for vague answers , so it wasn ’ t long before I revealed what I was . And everyone loved me . Hell , I was a superhero !     My amazing rescues and general bad guy ass-kickery instantly became legendary .
