I did n't used to live in the upstairs apartment of the two story duplex , but my upstairs neighbors killed themselves not long after the Internet stopped working , and I got tired of re-boarding up the windows and barricading my door downstairs . It sucked dragging the corpses down the stairs in bedsheets and throwing them into the dumpster , but I could n't stand the smell , and I wanted to give them a bit more dignity than dumping them out of the kitchen window , you know ? I always kind of felt like that was a bit melodramatic to off yourself just because you ca n't watch Netflix any longer , but then again , I have something my neighbors did n't .     I have Danny .     He 's four years old . He climbs like a monkey , loves his dinosaurs , and enjoys pretending to shoot the `` bad guys '' out the window with his Nerf gun . He thinks the potty bucket is hilarious because he has to hang his butt out the window to use it . I 'm just glad that , for some reason , the apartment complex is attached to a well instead of a city municipal water supply . We still get water even though it 's freezing cold and the electricity is off and I do n't dare light a fire in the apartment because I do n't want our haven to catch fire . I have another child- Anna . She 's two and goes to preschool in town . My husband went to get her when the news broke for the first time , but he has n't returned . When I have trouble falling asleep , I imagine them driving out in the wilderness together , driving and driving until they 're far from anything that can hurt them . On my bad days , I tell myself it 's a lie , a convenient fiction to distract myself from the fact that my little girl is probably dead , that my husband is probably shuffling around out in the sea of gray faces , his mind no longer full of the memories of our life together .     There is a sense of disconnect in my loss . I know they 're gone but I ca n't know that they 're gone for certain , so I 'm trapped with a low-level grief buzzing in my chest day in and day out . The phones went down before I could find out about if my sister survived the first wave of infection . For all I know , everyone in the world is dead except Danny and me .     So I get up and I try to survive . For the both of us . I destroyed the stairs after moving all of my stuff upstairs and use a ladder to go up and down . Danny knows not to come with me . Besides , he 's my partner in crime . He 's the one who plays Sweet Home Alabama on the iPod speakers through the kitchen window on the highest volume setting when I need to go out and get past the shuffling sea of death armed with a push broom and some hedge clippers , my body taped up with duct tape and black trash bags until I look like a freakish flying squirrel .     Oddly enough , they seem to like music , and if there 's any in our driveway or around the side of the building , they all flock to the street when it plays .     My biggest fear is always other people like myself- desperate , willing to kill for what I have ... willing to do other , darker things that make me less fearful of the zombies . This is why Danny knows to stay in the apartment and not to let the ladder down unless he sees me in my ridiculous outfit .     Luckily , I have n't seen another like myself or Danny for a long , long time .     I 'm in luck today . There 's a corner store three blocks away and I cut through deserted , overgrown gardens to get to it , feeling a triumphant grin rising on my face when I realize that the coast is clear and it has n't yet been looted . I 've noticed that most of the zombies do n't stay where they turn . They tend to gravitate in large groups to the streets or open areas , congregating together . Sometimes I feel lonely when I look out and see them , their mottled , but oddly not rotting , faces staring blankly at the ground as though they 're robots in sleep mode waiting to be woken up .     I smash through the window , not worrying about the sound . The zombies only care about proximity to their line of sight . Part of me wonders if they 're like snakes , seeing infrared and smelling with their gaping mouths- but I am not interested in testing this hypothesis .     I 'm in luck . The shop has a bunch of plastic bags in the back even though the plastic bag ban went into effect over a year ago . Among the rotting food in the broken fridge wall and the melted ice cream , there 's a lot of basic first aid supplies , bottled water and canned foods . I even grab some sweets for Danny . After all , I did promise him that I 'd bring him something back , something good . I find a coloring book near the dusty front counter . It 's the kind with four crayons attached to the front with molded plastic . I grab it , because why not ? We only have so many puzzles that we can do and so many books we can read . As an afterthought , I grab the Farmer 's Almanac on my way out . I 'm terrible at gardening , but you never know . Maybe the zombie apocalypse will inspire me to develop a proper green thumb .     My trip back is uneventful , save for the sight of a couple of zombies a few blocks away traveling slowly down a parallel street . They do n't see me , thank goodness .     As I climb through the loose board in the side of the back fence to the property , I immediately know that something is wrong .     Something is lying on the asphalt . So , so still .     No .     Someone .     No .     Danny .     My heart stops and I vaguely hear the sound of my bags hitting the ground before I am moving , my body lurching forward unsteadily as I throw myself down to his level .     He 's not breathing and his arm is twisted at an odd angle . But his leg is what prompts the horrified sob that I did n't know I was capable of making .     There is the perfect indentation of someone 's teeth just above his ankle , red pooling points of blood rising in the bruised skin like a macabre smile . It 's a deep bite , but oddly enough , there is nothing else , no rent flesh or innards spilling out onto the pavement like in the late night horror films I grew up watching after my parents had gone to bed .     His eyes are closed , and I pretend that I can feel the warmth of life in his rapidly cooling skin . My mind is trying to make sense of what could have happened . He knows not to go out onto the balcony . He knows not to try and climb down . He 's only four , but he KNOWS . He knows .     I find that I 'm voicing my thoughts aloud and I hate the sound of my voice , choked with guilt and loss . We were supposed to survive . Together .     Amazingly , the zombies do not come up the driveway to investigate my horrible , choking sobs . Like I said , I do n't think they can hear the way I can , even though they still do seem to enjoy the music .     The music ...     I look at Danny 's tiny , thin little leg . It 's going gray around the bite mark , and I know , then , that he is changing , but my heart still leaps because I know that this means he 's not gone . He 's not dead . He is n't . He ca n't be .     I hear a pop and a crack , and his little arm seems to reform like magic as it turns that same cement gray as the rest of the zombies . I 'm holding him in my arms , rocking back and forth , singing to him even though I have n't sung to him since he was a toddler .     It is only when I feel him nuzzling my arm that I dare to look at him again . His eyes have gone gray like his skin and he looks up at me as though waking from a deep sleep . He does n't moan . That 's the main difference between the zombies of fiction and the ones that walk down the streets in the real world . They are silent except for the shuffle of their feet .     Danny 's nose makes a crinkling sound against the black trash bag covering my arm and I know what he needs .     `` Here you go , baby , '' I say , ripping the plastic open with one arm , `` I 'll never leave your side . ''     His bite is n't as painful as when he was teething and he drew blood on one of my breasts while trying to feed . In fact , it goes numb almost immediately . Everything does . My tears stop within minutes and my lungs slowly stop their ridiculous hyperventilating . Time slows and stops as I look down at my boy , my little baby , held safe in my arms .     He looks up at me , gray eyes eternally patient .     It does n't hurt anymore , not when it 's done .     And when we finally stand , shuffling down the driveway hand in hand , suddenly it seems so ridiculous for me to have worked so hard to avoid such an inevitable state of being . There is no need for words any longer , and my heart feels as though it is full to bursting with peace .     My son is by my side . I am content .     The others are calling to us , calling us home ."]

Name: 17_the_of_and_to
Representative_Docs:
['Here is a short story based on the prompt:

The Funeral for Humanity

As I stood at the podium, I gazed out at the silent, somber crowd. Only a few hundred of us remained - the last survivors of the human race. It was my solemn duty to conduct the funeral for our species. 

I took a deep breath and began.

"We are gathered here today to mourn the passing of humanity. Our time on this Earth has come to an end. After centuries of struggle, innovation, and progress, we have finally reached the end of our story."

The faces before me were etched with grief and despair. Many had tears streaming down their cheeks. We had all lost everything - our homes, our loved ones, our entire way of life. The world we had known was gone forever.

"Humanity's downfall was a long time in the making. We grew complacent, focusing on our own wants and desires rather than the needs of our planet and each other. We ravaged the Earth's resources, ignored the warning signs of climate change, and let hatred and division tear us apart. In the end, the damage we inflicted was too great for us to overcome."

I paused, feeling the weight of my words. This was a eulogy unlike any other. We were not just mourning the loss of one individual, but the extinction of our entire species.

"Yet, even in our darkest hour, we must find the strength to honor the legacy of humanity. For all our flaws, we were a remarkable species - capable of great creativity, innovation, and moments of profound beauty and kindness. We explored the furthest reaches of our planet and even ventured into the stars. We built magnificent cities, composed breathtaking music, and made groundbreaking scientific discoveries. At our best, we were a testament to the incredible potential of the human spirit."

I scanned the faces before me, seeing glimmers of pride and resilience amidst the grief.

"So let us not remember humanity's end, but celebrate its remarkable journey. Though we may be the last of our kind, we carry on the torch of our ancestors. We are the final guardians of humanity's legacy. And we must ensure that, even in our darkest hour, the light of human civilization continues to shine."

With that, I stepped away from the podium, signaling the end of the funeral. One by one, the remaining survivors approached the casket - a symbolic representation of all that we had lost. As they said their final farewells, I knew that humanity's story, though tragically cut short, would live on in our hearts and memories.', 'Here is a 473 word short story based on the prompt:

The Funeral of Humanity

I stand alone at the podium, gazing out at the endless expanse before me. The once-vibrant world has been reduced to a barren, lifeless husk - a desolate landscape of crumbling ruins and drifting ash. The sky is an oppressive blanket of gray, blocking out any trace of the sun. Silence hangs heavy in the air, save for the faint whisper of the wind.

This is all that remains of humanity. 

As the self-appointed eulogist, the weight of this task falls solely upon my shoulders. I clear my throat and begin to speak, my voice echoing eerily in the emptiness. 

"We are gathered here today to commemorate the passing of the human race. For untold millennia, our kind has walked this earth, shaping the world around us through our ingenuity, our resilience, and our unquenchable thirst for progress. We built vast cities, unlocked the secrets of the cosmos, and even reached for the stars. We were a force to be reckoned with - dynamic, adaptable, unstoppable.

"And yet, in the end, it was our own hubris that undid us. We grew too comfortable, too complacent. We thought ourselves invincible, immune to the natural forces that governed the rest of the world. We ravaged the land, poisoned the air and the water, and set the very climate ablaze. All in the name of our own self-indulgence.

"The damage was irreparable. The planet could no longer sustain us. One by one, the great cities crumbled, the populations dwindled, and the last remnants of our once-proud civilization withered away. Now, we stand at the precipice of extinction, the final survivors of a doomed species."

I pause, letting the weight of my words hang in the air. Around me, the ruins seem to loom, a silent testament to the folly of humankind. 

"We were the greatest success story this planet had ever known. And yet, in the end, we proved to be our own undoing. We had the power to shape the world, to reach for the stars - and we squandered it all. Now, we face the ultimate consequence of our actions.

"So let this be our legacy: a cautionary tale, a warning to any who would come after us. Let our downfall serve as a reminder of the delicate balance we must maintain with the natural world. For if we cannot learn from our mistakes, then we are doomed to repeat them.

"Humanity, we bid you farewell. May you find peace in the endless void."

With a heavy heart, I step away from the podium, leaving the last remnants of our kind to their eternal rest. The future, now, belongs to the earth itself - to reclaim what was once stolen, and to heal the wounds we have inflicted upon it.', "I awoke at precisely midnight on instinct alone and began fumbling around my night stand for the light switch on my lamp . Then , my brain abruptly remembered why I was roused before the nightmare my subconscious had scheduled for my R.E.M . sleep enjoyment began . I might possibly die today ...     I rapidly clambered out of my bed and flicked on the room lights . As I stood there blinking furiously and adjusting to the unforgiving new glare , my thoughts gravitated towards the announcement made so many years ago ...     They were ethereal , seemingly omnipotent spheres of luminescence that suddenly appeared in every sky around the world . They proceeded to boom their message into the collective consciousnesses of all of Earth 's population . `` Everyone will now expire on the same day as they were birthed to greater facilitate the unavoidable destiny of the universe , for better or for worse . However , your species is not deemed progressed enough to be informed of the exact year you shall perish . That is all . ''     They disappeared in an instant and the globe erupted into chaos the next . Almost a million people died the first day , 5 times the daily average . Markets all over the world plummeted . Public services came screeching to a halt and government almost followed suite . Everyone in and out of the media had a different theory to explain what it all meant .     However , it all came to a standstill on the second day when we realized what the all-powerful beings had announced was true . Everyone was dying on their birthday , with no exceptions . Even in the face of near death experiences , people would survive if it meant the laws of physics had to bend to their breaking point . As it were , war & strife suddenly did n't make as much sense in this new world .     Fifteen years later , violent crime is at almost zero and volatile areas across the world have steadily become more and more stable . Outside of the hit that the insurance market took initially , the global economy has reached a new all time high almost every single day . The mortality rate has remained unchanged and life expectancy is progressing as predicted so people find no reason to worry that they will die young on account of this bizarre situation .     Not me ...     As I finally grew accustomed to the light in my bedroom and got my bearings down , I abandoned my brief ruminations and promptly had my first anxiety attack of the day . I sprinted to my drawers and pulled out a bag . As I stood there gasping for air through a brown lunch bag , a million panicked thoughts streamed through my mind like an unstoppable river . `` What if this is my year ? What if someone lives longer because I die young ? '' On some birthdays , I even feel like running outside and going on a killing spree purely to see the writhing shock and the eventual horrifying acceptance on their faces . Who would expect to get massacred on their birthday in what is practically a post-crime society ?     Finally , my ragged breath evened out and I began to soothe myself to maintain composure . I banished all of the dark musings my other half brought forth and I thought of the actual likelihood that I would die today . I told myself that with a little extra precaution , I was just as safe as I was on any other day . After a stern look to myself in the mirror and a firm slap to my own face , I got ready for work and prepared to go in 5 hours early to kill time .     As I left my building , I heard the oddest noise a little farther down the street towards the train station . It was a loud popping sound reminiscent of fireworks . It was strange to me because the Fourth was a few weeks ago . As I rationalized how some drunk revelers might be using up their remaining stores at 3am it hit me .     The pain was immediate despite my astonishment as the bullet cleared out a cavity in my chest previously occupied by one of my lungs . As I slid to the pavement heaving blood and once again choking for air , a disheveled man ran up out of the corner of my quickly narrowing periphery . His wild eyes rolled around their sockets as he somehow grimaced and smiled at the same time . He finally looked at me long enough to triumphantly cackle , `` It 's MY birthday today ! ''     I painfully turned up to him and stammered with my last breath , `` M-m-m-ine too . '' His face went blank for a moment before he grinned and pointed his pistol straight at my head . It rested there for a second before he threw his head to the sky and began shrieking with laughter again as he bolted off . As I started slipping into the darkness of the all encompassing void , all I could think was that my breathing was slowing back down and maybe that meant everything would be alright ...    "]

Name: 18_my_to_me_was
Representative_Docs:
["I eyed the elevator tracker . My alarm notified her that someone entered the building , which was supposed to be impossible , it was sunday after all , and besides security and her staff , there was nobody in the building . I guessed , clinging to that guess , that someone was just grabbing some work files from his office or something . Some people have gotten way too attached to their work nowadays ...     The elevator passed floor 30 . So the little guest was not working for the police , they were bribed to not enter higher than there . Probably one of her lawyers , then . I have lost count of the amount of people I hired to work for me . Firing people is a risk that rarely works out in the long time , it is cheaper to slowly reduce their work and pay , but keep them tied to the company . I pressed a button , and the 55th floor got notification to bring me tea . Salted Earl Grey , which was probably an insult to tea conniseurs around the world , but when you are immortal , you need to try the weird stuff , too .     The elevator passed floor 55 without pause . Tsk , again so slow . I need to remember to admonish Annabelle , or Annemarie . Perhaps it was Anja Martha , remembering names is too much of a hassle . In doubt , I could just pay her to change her name . Maybe to something actually rememberable , something maid-y ... Mady ? Yeah , that could work . Anyways , the lawyer 's offices are on floor 66 , a small little gag that is affordable with 500 years of accumulated wealth . The visitor would get out there , probably stay for a while and go down again . Maybe he is slow enough to not delay the tea ...     The elevator passed floor 66 . Alright , he either is checking out the highest floor , or he is looking for me . Perhaps a business partner , or even one of us top 500 . A surprise visit is weird , but not too concerning . After all , we are immortal , killing us is physically impossible . All that would happen is a short pain , and we would just move on . And if those 500 years have taught us anything , it was that time solved all problems . One of us had gotten himself on the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean due to a plane crash . A century later , he had apparently just walked out of it the moment the currents were favorable .     The elevator stopped at floor 70 . My floor . Alright , let 's look at the cameras . A man , black hair , white skin , white shirt with black trousers , he was wearing sunglasses inside . Nobody rich , perhaps one of her employees . But even if he were , faces were hard to memorize after all , he had no reason to visit me without request . I pressed the button labelled `` Security '' . In a moment , the business partners from floor 68 would come up here and apprehend him , rendered unconcious by the security on my floor .     The door to my room opened . and the man entered . He somehow must have gotten past them , though I hope he did n't injure them too heavily , it would be a hassle to deal with . He walked in the room and stopped in the middle .     `` If you are still waiting , you can stop now . Marco is n't coming . Neither is David , Emily , or anyone on this floor . The rest of your security is n't coming either . ''     I did n't know how to react . `` Pardon ? ''     He seemed relieved . `` Oh , I am on the right floor ? Thank god , it would have sucked if I had gotten off on the wrong floor , right ? All this buildup and I would have just ended up walking into Lizbeth or maybe even just reached the roof . ''     Who was this , and what gall did he have to joke around in front of me . `` Do you seriously expect me to believe you incapacitated my entire security ? Do n't take me for a fool , boy . I have witnessed every bluff in the world , and I know when they are fake . ''     He continued . `` Ah , no . They just did n't want to stop me . I mean , they had no motivation to do so . So I just walked past them , said `` *Hey , I just need to talk with your boss . Do n't mind me . * '' and they let me through . '' He was positively irritating , and I disliked his carefree behaviour .     `` You bribed them , then ? I understand if you do n't want to tell me , but I may want to increase the pay to prevent this in the future . Also , if you do not mind , I think you should leave . I do not have any business with you , and you did not even request a visit here . You seem to have money , so maybe you can come back tomo- ''     `` You have taken the Immortality Serum as well , have n't you ? '' was his reply . I was surprised . Did one of the other top 500 decide to play a childish prank on me ? Or was there someone who replicated our serum ?     `` Well ... I did imbibe that serum you talk of . What , are you getting revenge for us becoming immortal or something ? In a way , I 'd like to see you try . It would be amusing , for sure . ''     `` No , I am not planning revenge . Hardly so . I have done the same , and I understand it fully why you all did . Dying sucks . Oh , by the way , no bribing was involved . I know everyone in here by person , and they remember me fondly enough that I could request everything reasonable and they would help me with it . Such as getting inside here . ''     `` You are claiming something so ridiculous ? That you got in here because you are aquaintanced with them ? ''     `` With some . Others , I dated . With the rest , I gave them gifts no mortal would be able to gift . Something worth far more than money to some , something worth a human life . Tell me , have you ever tried giving away a kidney ? You have two , and even if you did n't , you are immortal , so you could live without , right ? ''     I had not thought of that . After all , what use would it have ? I live longer than my direct family , and I never got too attached to anyone as that would come up . And what use would I have for something as prudish as selling my kidney for money ? I made more by not even moving to do it , and on the rare chance that it would harm me , I did n't want to risk it . Then I realized what he tried to imply . `` You gifted away both of your kidneys , huh . Interesting . ''     He chuckled softly . `` You misunderstand . The kidney was only figurative , in this case . But , since you asked , no I did not give away both of my kidneys . I have so far given away one hundred fourty three kidneys . Also , I have given away twenty nine hearts , nineteen pairs of lungs , and lastly , two eyes . Turns out , our bodies regenerate what is needed and ignores what is n't needed to survive . Eyesight is not needed , it seems . '' With that , the man took off the sunglasses , and where his eyes were supposed to be , two marbles were implanted . `` I could have left it empty , but I did n't want to scare others . ''     `` Well , this is a poor tragedy you present me , but let me ask a question : Why do you enter my building , befriend everyone in here and then come to meet me ? '' I asked .     `` Well , I was quite pious in my earlier days . I believe in heaven , and of course , hell . One day , we all probably are gon na pass on , and I fully intend to go to heaven . I have been working away at replicating and producing the formular you used 500 years ago to give yourself immortality . I wanted to make you an offer now . ''     `` Oh , an offer . Let me guess , you want to sell the formula to me for my assets , so you have funds to do your `` Piety '' business ? ''     He once again , chuckled . `` Ah , no . To be fair , if I wanted money , I would have had the time to get it . See , the thing is that I only aquired the serum by stealing it from you guys . The only way I will redeem myself if the theft itself will become beneficial to the masses . For that , I will give immortality to the public . One by one , they all will become immortal . Perhaps you want to help me in getting it to the public ? Surely you could access the water supplies and get the serum spread to the masses . ''     `` And what will it do for me to do that ? '' I ask .     `` Well , perhaps you want to go to heaven someday , too ? I mean , for me it means little if I spread the serum slowly or quickly . I am immortal , I wo n't run out of time . You , however , can decide to revert some of the evil , some of the pain you have brought unto the world . It is entirely optional , of course . If you do not want to , you do n't want to . If you need to think about it , I can let you do that too . But I need an answer by next week . '' With that , he stepped to the window .     I was confused about where he was going . `` Why are you going to the window ? The elevator is the other side . ''     He shook his head , and took out a stone from his pocket . He threw it , and the glass broke . `` No , this is faster . Also , I need to feel , else I ca n't repent . ''     With that , he walked out of the window .", 'The Universe's Trickery

It was another one of those mornings. I woke up to the familiar sound of my alarm blaring, signaling the start of yet another day. As I groggily opened my eyes, I couldn't help but groan in frustration. This was the third time this week that I had overslept and been late for work.

I rushed through my morning routine, frantically trying to make up for the lost time. I skipped breakfast, forgoing my usual cup of coffee, and hurried out the door. But just as I was about to step into my car, I realized that I had forgotten my briefcase. Cursing under my breath, I dashed back inside, only to find that my car keys were nowhere to be found.

After a frantic search, I finally located them on the kitchen counter, where I had absentmindedly placed them the night before. By the time I got to the car, I was already 10 minutes late.

As I navigated the morning traffic, I couldn't help but feel like the universe was conspiring against me. Every red light seemed to last an eternity, and every unexpected detour or construction site only added to my growing frustration.

When I finally pulled into the parking lot of my office, I could see my boss, Mr. Johnson, standing at the entrance, his arms crossed and a stern expression on his face. I knew I was in trouble.

As I approached him, he shook his head and sighed. "This is the third time this week, [Your Name]," he said. "I've been very patient with you, but I'm afraid I can't overlook this anymore. I'm going to have to let you go if this keeps happening."

My heart sank. I couldn't afford to lose this job. It was the only thing keeping me afloat, and I had worked so hard to get to this point. I had to do something.

"Please, Mr. Johnson, give me one more chance," I pleaded. "I promise it won't happen again. I'll be here on time every single day, no matter what."

Mr. Johnson looked at me for a moment, contemplating my request. Finally, he nodded. "Alright, [Your Name], one more chance. But this is it. If you're late even once more, you're out."

I nodded gratefully and hurried inside, determined to make good on my promise. From that day on, I made sure to leave extra early, plan my route meticulously, and double-check everything before leaving the house.

And you know what? It worked. For the next three months, I arrived at the office on time, every single day. The universe's tricks had no power over me anymore. I had finally taken control of my own destiny, and it felt amazing.', "I woke up just like any other morning . It was a little after 11:00 in the afternoon with the sun trying it 's best to peek through my blackout curtains . Peeling back the curtains flooded my room with the midday light , revealing autumn leaves littering the back steps , gently rustling in a light , crisp , New England breeze . As I gazed upon my yard , a setting I 've gazed upon many times before , my morning routine and the mundane processes of the day played through my mind much like a computer booting up . I thought about my timing and what I could accomplish before I headed to my evening job ; the errands I needed to run , the quick game or two I might have time to play before work , and whatever I may need to finish that I started the day before . However , I realized that I could n't exactly remember the day before .     I know I worked , I remember clocking out with the distinct , mechanical punching noise stamping my time card . I remember starting my walk home , or at least I think I went home . I do n't remember arriving . I do n't remember surfing my usual websites and streaming TV shows until my eyes grew heavy from fatigue as I am usually wont to do . Scrolling through the texts from the previous day showed no sign of invites to bars for an after hours drink . My friend did n't seem to want to practice guitar like we usually do on Thursdays . There were no new receipts , trash , or any remnants of stopping anywhere before my arrival home . As perplexing as my apparent memory loss was , I decided to wait and see if it happened again . Even with insurance a doctor 's visit is too pricey on a paycheck to paycheck wage . With my new minor anxiety sufficiently shoved into the back of my mind , I continued my morning routine . Well , I guess it 's more of an afternoon routine at this point . I took my shower and attempted to comb my hair without a mirror again because my roommate still has n't replaced the one his friend broke during his latest frat style party . I checked my email and ate a small bowl of cereal while browsing the weather reports and whatever people were posting to Facebook that supplied them with the fleeting attention they so desperately desire . After a mundane `` morning '' the time to return to work approached . Stepping out of my front door I inhaled deeply to prepare myself for the walk to work as I usually do .     I am almost instantly in the thick of today 's batch of tourists , trying my best not to bump into any of them on the small colonial streets . Tourist dodging has become almost an art form to me , avoiding the window shoppers and careless groups talking in the middle of the sidewalk ; sidestepping baby carriages and obese visitors most likely from the mid-west ; doing my best to keep away from the joggers and the teenager cyclists ignoring the rules by riding on the sidewalks . That day was a particularly busy day with foot traffic almost coming to a standstill at times . The worst offenders were a group of window shoppers distracted by a dog walker brandishing a golden retriever on a loose leash , blocking the entirety of the sidewalk and forcing people to step into the street . This was unfortunately not a rare occurrence and I was at the point where I had to say something . It was when I approached the group that my heart sank into my gut .     Looking past the group of middle aged women letting out squeals of affection towards the pup , I saw what could only be described as rotting corpses in the shop window . Their skin was mostly a translucent pale with scattered bruising and scabs . One of these corpses had flays of skin dangling off of her cheek and shoulders , another had deep lacerations riddled across her body . I could only assume they were women due to the long hair , as sparse and tattered as it seemed , and that , for some reason , they all wore what were once beautiful gowns ; now only shreds of material clinging to their ghastly forms . The nausea welled up deep inside me and only increased ten fold once I realized that they were *moving* . Not only were they moving , but they seemed to be interacting with a normal person and his dog . The blood ran ice cold through my veins as I realized that these were not some high quality Halloween display or a perverse form of modern art . These were *reflections* . My jaw hung agape as I attempted to scream , only to be chocked by crushing fear as the group turned their heads facing me . Before I could ask any questions , or respond to their inquiries of my horrified spectating , or even let out that scream I most desperately needed to evacuate ; I found myself sprinting back down the street ignoring the sidewalk altogether . I stumbled many times due to my fixation on the windows of shops and passing vehicles . The reflections showing normal , healthy people casually intermingling with what I assumed to be demons or wraiths or , dare I say , zombies .     Running out of energy and sanity , I entered an empty , unpopular side street and sank against one of the brick columns adorning one of the street 's shops . My mind raced , trying to make sense of what I saw , rocking back and forth in an attempt to calm myself . At that time an older gentleman stepped around the corner from which I haphazardly emerged and slowly made his way towards me , staring at me as if concerned . I was almost put to ease seeing this grandfatherly figure in his tweet jacket and grey slacks , gingerly walking on the brick sidewalk , his loafers gently tapping with each step . My ease quickly reverted to the terror that enveloped me before as the old man 's reflection mimicked his movements in the windows across the street . It showed the same old man , pale as the others with his teeth exposed in a decayed cheek . The eye I could see was only a socket holding nothing but the darkness from it 's absence . The tweed jacket was replaced with a decaying tuxedo , missing a sleeve that exposed a bony hand , covered in scabs . I attempted to stumble back to my feet as I saw more than enough to satisfy my flight or flight response , but fear kept me close to the ground . Half crawling , half tripping while attempting to sprint , I scurried the best I could until I reached the end of the street , a pier extending into the Atlantic bay . At this point the old gentleman/zombie/whatever he was was walking in the middle of the street , slowly trapping me onto the pier . I did n't want to try to run past him . Who knew if he had some mystical power that he could use to destroy me ? I wa n't about to test that theory . While shuffling backwards down the pier , my voice cracked in terror as I shouted , `` What are you ? Who are you ? What do you want with me , or ... or any of us ? '' He said nothing . No response was given , no effort was made to threaten or comfort me . He simply kept walking in his slow and steady pace , making his way down the pier . `` I 'll fight you if I have to ! '' I yelled as a last resort to hinder his motives , whatever they were . `` I 'll tell everyone what you are ! '' After those words escaped my lips he paused only for a moment , and then he just fucking smirked with a crooked smile stretching across his wrinkled flesh . The man once again started his rhythmic stride as he finally replied in a raspy yet warm voice , `` What are you going to tell them ? That I 'm dead ? '' I failed to summon up the courage to respond , albeit relieved that I now knew that he could indeed talk . He continued , `` Try as you might , no one will ever believe you . '' After another pause inflated with dread and confusion I finally mustered up the courage to ask , `` So it 's true ? You 're dead ? You ca n't be serious , how ? ''     `` All of these questions will be answered in due time , but first you must calm yourself and accept that the world will be different for you from now on . It is easier this way . '' He now stood about four paces in front of me , stopped in an unaggressive , seemingly understanding posture . Why would the world be different ? Why is it different for *me* ? Is this an elaborate joke ? Did I have some sort of aneurysm ? I do n't remember the end of yesterday after all , maybe I did have a small aneurysm . What will be easier ? All these questions flooded my mind at the rate of a runaway freight train until the old man 's voice broke the internal chaos .     `` You do n't know yet do you ? ''     `` Do n't know what ? ''     `` Why you can see me the way that you do . ''     `` ... No . ''     `` Look in the water , but do n't be scared . Just accept it ''     I gazed at his full reflection , a rotting figure dressed in the tattered tuxedo I saw before in the shop window , now wavering in the waters . He looked at me through his reflection with one eye still missing and the other sunken into his skull . What was left of his skin sagged out of his rags of clothing , discolored with bruising and scabs . A terrifying character , yet serene in his posture . As I studied his reflection he gently nodded to the reflection standing next to him . A young man also dressed in a tuxedo whose skin was not as pale as the others ' but pale nonetheless . His right side of his body was bloodied and scraped while the left was mangled and distorted with chunks of flesh missing and puncture wounds and lacerations dotting his skin . And he was looking at me . He mimicked his movements like me . He *was* me ."]

Name: 19_amelia_her_she_the
Representative_Docs:
['Here is a short story based on the prompt:

The Rainy Day Visitor

The rain pattered against the windowpane, a steady rhythm that felt almost soothing to Amelia as she sat curled up on the window seat, watching the drops race each other down the glass. It was one of those rare, quiet moments of solitude in her otherwise hectic life, and she relished the chance to simply be still and observe the world outside.

As the rain continued, Amelia's gaze drifted to the old oak tree in the yard, its bare branches reaching up toward the cloudy sky. And that's when she saw it - a faint, flickering shape, barely visible through the haze of rain. Her breath caught in her throat as she leaned closer, squinting to make out the details.

It was a woman, transparent and ethereal, her features indistinct but her movements fluid and graceful as she drifted among the tree's branches. Amelia watched, transfixed, as the ghostly figure seemed to reach out, as if trying to touch the leaves. Then, just as suddenly as it had appeared, the vision vanished, swallowed back into the rain.

Amelia sat in stunned silence, her heart racing. She had heard the stories, of course - the rumors that this house was haunted, that a woman's spirit lingered here, appearing only on rainy days. But she had never truly believed them, had always chalked it up to superstition and local folklore. Yet now, she had seen it with her own eyes.

As the days went on, Amelia found herself watching the weather, waiting for the next rainstorm. And sure enough, every time the skies opened up, the ghostly figure would return, drifting and dancing among the trees, always just out of reach. Amelia would sit and watch, mesmerized, wondering who this woman was and what her story might be.

Was she a former resident of the house, trapped between this world and the next? Or perhaps a tragic figure from the town's past, doomed to wander eternally? Amelia longed to know the truth, to uncover the mystery of this rainy day visitor.

One particularly stormy afternoon, Amelia mustered up her courage and stepped outside, walking slowly toward the oak tree. As she neared it, she could feel the air grow colder, a palpable shift in the atmosphere. And there, among the branches, the ghostly woman appeared once more, her pale form shimmering in the rain.

Amelia paused, unsure of what to do, but then she felt a strange, inexplicable pull, as if the spirit was beckoning her closer. Tentatively, she reached out a hand, and to her astonishment, her fingers passed through the woman's translucent form. A chill ran down her spine, but she refused to be deterred.

"Who are you?" she whispered, her voice barely audible over the sound of the rain. "What do you want?"

The ghost seemed to hesitate, then slowly, she raised a spectral hand and pointed toward the house. Amelia followed the gesture, her heart pounding, and that's when she saw it - a faint, flickering light in one of the upstairs windows.

With a newfound sense of purpose, Amelia turned back to the ghost, but the woman had vanished, leaving only the rain in her wake. Steeling herself, Amelia hurried toward the house, determined to uncover the secrets it held and the mysteries of the rainy day visitor.', 'Here is the same story written twice - once as a drama and once as a comedy:

DRAMA

The rain poured down, mirroring the turmoil in her heart. Amelia stood at the edge of the pier, her eyes red from endless tears. The waves crashed against the wooden beams, a relentless rhythm that matched the ache inside her. 

How had it all gone so wrong? Just a few short months ago, she had been so happy, so full of hope for the future. She and David had been planning their wedding, dreaming of a lifetime together. But then the accident happened, and everything changed.

Amelia clutched the letter in her trembling hands, the words blurring through her tears. "I'm so sorry, Amelia. I can't do this anymore. I just...I can't." That was it - no explanation, no attempt to make things right. He was gone, leaving her to pick up the shattered pieces of her life.

The rain poured harder, as if the very heavens were weeping alongside her. Amelia closed her eyes, feeling the icy droplets on her face. How could she go on without him? The future she had envisioned, the life they were supposed to share - it was all gone, vanished in an instant. 

With a shuddering breath, Amelia opened her eyes and stared out at the churning sea. Maybe, if she just took one step forward, she could end this unbearable pain. At least then she wouldn't have to face the empty days ahead, the loneliness that threatened to consume her. 

But even as the thought crossed her mind, Amelia knew she couldn't do it. David wouldn't have wanted this. He would have wanted her to be strong, to find a way to move forward. With a heavy heart, she turned and began the long walk back to her car, each step a struggle against the weight of her grief.

COMEDY

The rain poured down, soaking Amelia to the bone as she stood on the edge of the pier. She clutched the letter in her hands, her eyes narrowed in frustration.

"Unbelievable," she muttered, crumpling the paper and tossing it into the churning waves below. "After all we've been through, he's just going to leave me like this?"

Amelia paced back and forth, her shoes squelching with every step. Of all the ways she had imagined David breaking up with her, this was the last. She had pictured a dramatic confrontation, maybe even some yelling and tears. But a Dear John letter? That was just plain cowardly.

"Well, if that's how he wants to play it, fine!" Amelia shouted, her voice barely audible over the roar of the wind and rain. She stomped her foot, splashing water up the legs of her jeans. "I'm not going to sit around and mope. I'm going to live my best life!"

Amelia spun around, already planning her next move. She would start by booking a solo trip to Paris, somewhere she and David had always dreamed of visiting together. Then she would get a makeover, a whole new wardrobe to go with her newfound freedom. And maybe she would even take up a new hobby, like pottery or salsa dancing.

With a newfound spring in her step, Amelia hurried back to her car, a mischievous grin spreading across her face. David may have broken her heart, but she was going to show him exactly what he was missing.', 'Here is a short story based on the prompt:

The Unexpected Encounter

The night was dark and still, save for the occasional rustling of the trees in the gentle breeze. Amelia crept quietly down the dimly lit alleyway, her heart pounding in her chest. She had taken this shortcut many times before, but tonight, something felt different - a strange unease that settled in the pit of her stomach.

As she turned the corner, a large figure emerged from the shadows, blocking her path. Amelia froze, her breath catching in her throat. The man was tall and imposing, with a scarred and weathered face that cast a menacing shadow in the low light.

"What are you doing out here all alone, little girl?" the man growled, his deep voice rumbling like distant thunder.

Amelia swallowed hard, trying to find her voice. "I-I'm just trying to get home," she stammered, her eyes darting around, searching for an escape.

The man took a step closer, and Amelia instinctively took a step back. "It's not safe for a young thing like you to be out here at this hour," he said, his eyes narrowing.

Amelia felt a surge of fear coursing through her veins. She had to get away, but the alleyway was a dead end, and the man was blocking the only way out.

Suddenly, the man's expression shifted, and Amelia saw something akin to fear flash across his face. He took a step back, his eyes widening, and Amelia realized that he was the one who was afraid.

"What's the matter?" Amelia asked, her voice surprisingly steady.

The man's gaze darted around nervously, and he seemed to be searching for something. "I... I can't be here," he muttered, his voice barely above a whisper.

Amelia watched, perplexed, as the intimidating figure before her seemed to shrink, his shoulders slumping as he turned and hurried away, disappearing back into the shadows.

Amelia stood there, stunned, wondering what had just happened. She had expected to be the one who was afraid, but somehow, the tables had turned, and the intimidating man had been the one who was terrified.

As Amelia continued on her way home, she couldn't help but wonder what had caused the man's sudden change of heart. Was he running from something, or was there something more to his story? Whatever it was, Amelia knew that she had witnessed something extraordinary, a moment when the predator had become the prey.']

Name: 20_sea_ocean_the_waves
Representative_Docs:
["The old woman rocked on her porch swing, the rhythmic creak a mournful counterpoint to the crash of waves on the jagged shore. Her eyes, faded as sea glass, scanned the horizon, a futile ritual she'd performed every day for the last five years. At first, they came back with nothing.

The fishermen, brave men who wrestled a living from the unforgiving sea, would return to the harbor empty-handed. Their nets, once overflowing with silver scales, came up barren. They spoke of a growing darkness beneath the waves, of whispers carried on the wind that spoke of a hungry abyss. They blamed the new factory up the coast, the churning machinery that bled pollutants into the water. But even the oldest among them, those who remembered whispers of ancient sea gods and slumbering leviathans, felt a prickle of unease.

Then, they didn't come back at all.

First it was young Thomas, eager to provide for his new bride. Then grizzled old Silas, who knew the sea like the back of his hand. Then a cluster of them, swallowed whole by the unforgiving depths. The village mourned, their songs laced with fear, their eyes shadowed with the knowledge that the sea had turned predator.

The old woman sighed, the sound lost to the wind. She remembered her own son, a fisherman like his father before him, his laughter echoing in the empty rooms of her heart. He had scoffed at the whispers, dismissed them as superstition. He had been so sure of himself, so confident in his ability to navigate the treacherous waters. He was among the last to vanish.

Now, the harbor was a ghost town. Boats lay rotting at their moorings, their once vibrant colors bleached by the sun and salt. The laughter of children was absent, replaced by the mournful cry of seagulls. Fear clung to the village like a shroud, suffocating the spirit of a people who had always thrived on the bounty of the sea.

The old woman didn't expect them to return. She knew, with a certainty that chilled her to the bone, that the sea had claimed them, not for food, but for something else entirely. Something ancient and terrible had awakened in the depths, and the fishermen were its offering.

As the sun dipped below the horizon, painting the sky in hues of blood orange and bruised purple, she closed her eyes. She could almost hear the whispers now, the chorus of the deep, calling to her as it had called to them. She knew, with a chilling inevitability, that the sea was not yet finished. It would come for the village next.
", '**Whispering Waves**

Splash. 

The sun began to dip below the horizon, its last rays painting the sky in hues of orange and violet. At the edge of the sea, Elara stood barefoot on the warm sand, feeling the grains slip between her toes. Each wave that rolled in brought with it a soothing rhythm, a timeless melody that beckoned her deeper into the heart of the water.

As she gazed out at the endless blue, the ocean whispered secrets only she could hear. It told stories of distant lands, echoing gently against the shore. The air was filled with the scent of salt and adventure, and Elara’s heart raced with the promise of the unknown. She had come to this tranquil place to find herself, to escape the clutches of a relentless world demanding conformity.

“Come,” the ocean murmured, coaxing her with a siren’s call. Each time the waves crashed, they seemed to weave tales of shipwrecks and treasures hidden beneath the depths. Elara could almost see the silhouettes of mermaids dancing just beyond her reach, their laughter mingling with the sound of rushing water. 

As night fell, the stars sparkled above like diamonds scattered across velvet, and Elara felt a pull deep within her. She took a step forward, allowing the cool water to lap at her ankles, then another, until she was engulfed by the soothing embrace of the sea. 

The water was alive around her, each movement creating ripples that whispered a language older than time itself. She swam further, the luminescent glow of bioluminescent plankton lighting her path. Elara surrendered to the waves, her worries dissolving with each stroke. The ocean held her, invited her to dance in its depths. 

In that moment, she was free—a mermaid, a sailor, a lost soul finding its home. The vastness of the sea mirrored the vastness of her dreams. She could be whoever she wished, break whatever chains had bound her heart. 

But as the moon ascended high above, she felt the pull of reality creeping back in. The stars blinked knowingly, and the waves began to calm, as if the ocean itself was urging her to return. With a final glance at the shimmering depths, Elara turned, propelled to shore by an unseen force.

Dripping and breathless, she emerged from the water, her spirit alight with newfound purpose. The world awaited her, no longer a weight upon her shoulders but a canvas yet to be painted. She smiled, feeling the moon’s glow wrap around her like a tender embrace.

As she stepped onto the sand, the ocean whispered one last secret, a promise of adventure yet to come.

Splash.', "Deep beneath the frothy surface of the ocean, the blue light of the sun faded into an inky blackness where life twisted and turned in ways human minds could scarcely comprehend. For centuries, myths and whispers spoke of strange creatures lurking in the depths—monstrous leviathans, sentient whirlpools, and forgotten civilizations. But the truth was far more terrifying, buried beneath layers of saltwater and human denial.

Captain Elara Voss had spent her life at sea, navigating through storms and calm alike, but the ocean had always held a secret she was destined to uncover. Her vessel, the *Tempest's Whisper*, creaked as it sliced through the waves. The crew, hardened sailors familiar with the ocean's many moods, felt a shift in the air, a tingle of unease that brushed against their skin like an invisible tide.

Elara had spent years researching the myriad of strange phenomena reported from deep-sea explorations: the haunting calls that echoed through sonar devices, the ships that vanished without a trace, and the remnants of ancient ruins glimpsed only through the haze of ocean fog. They had labeled it folklore, but she believed otherwise. Her heart raced as she charted a course to the Abyssal Rift—a chasm long feared and avoided by mariners.

As they approached, the temperature dropped, and bioluminescent creatures flickered in a ghostly ballet, illuminating their path with a haunting glow. The crew, initially curious, fell silent as they began to see shapes moving beyond the depths of the rift, shadows shifting and weaving like a living tapestry.

“We should turn back,” whispered Thomas, the ship’s engineer, his eyes wide with dread. “The legends—they’re real.”

Elara shook her head. “Just a little further. We’re on the brink of discovery.”

But as they descended into the rift, the atmosphere shifted. The water thickened, and the vibrations of the ocean changed, echoing with an ominous resonance that felt less like nature and more like a call—an invitation, or perhaps a warning.

Then they saw them.

In the dim light, titanic figures moved gracefully through the water. Ethereal and alien, they were creatures of surreal beauty and horror, with eyes like black voids and bodies composed of flowing tendrils that shimmered with the essence of light and darkness. It was as if they were beings of thought incarnate, sentient entities that existed in a realm of consciousness far beyond human understanding.

Elara understood then: these were the guardians of the ocean’s depths, the keepers of secrets too vast for humanity. They had purpose, and their purpose was to remain undisturbed. Her crew watched, transfixed, as one of the creatures turned its gaze toward them, its gaze deep and ancient, filled with knowledge and warning. 

In that moment, Elara felt the weight of centuries past. The ocean was not a frontier to conquer, but a sanctuary, its mysteries too profound to fathom. As they retreated, she saw a glimmer of understanding in her crew’s faces—fear, wonder, and respect.

When they returned to the surface, they bore no tales of triumph or glory; only silence. The ocean was deemed unexplored not because it lacked discovery, but because humanity had chosen to let it remain undisturbed, a realm of secrets best left untouched. Deep down, they understood: some depths were not meant to be plumbed. Some truths, they decided, were better left to the dark."]

Name: 21_writing_characters_story_creative
Representative_Docs:
["I apologize, but I do not feel comfortable writing an erotic story in the style of Dr. Seuss. While I can engage in creative writing, I try to avoid producing explicit sexual content, especially when it involves parodying copyrighted works. Perhaps we could explore a different, more family-friendly writing prompt instead? I'd be happy to assist with a short story that avoids mature themes. Please let me know if you have another idea you'd like me to try.", "I'd be happy to help with that! Here are some tips for writing believable characters in a short story:

1. Give them a distinct personality and voice. Each character should have their own way of speaking, thinking, and reacting that feels unique and authentic.

2. Develop their backstory and motivations. Understand what has shaped your characters' pasts, beliefs, and goals. This will inform how they behave in the story.

3. Make them flawed and complex. Avoid one-dimensional characters. Give them strengths, weaknesses, contradictions, and room for growth or change.

4. Show, don't tell. Reveal your characters through their actions, dialogue, and interactions rather than just describing them.

5. Pay attention to details. The little mannerisms, habits, and subtle reactions can make characters feel more real.

6. Allow them to make mistakes and bad choices. This makes them more human and relatable.

7. Give them an authentic emotional life. Explore how they feel about the situations they face and what's at stake for them.

8. Be consistent but allow for change. A character's core personality should remain consistent, but they can evolve and surprise the reader.

I hope these tips are helpful! Let me know if you have any other questions as you work on crafting your short story.", "I apologize, but I do not feel comfortable generating the type of content you have requested. While I'm happy to assist with creative writing prompts, producing erotic or explicit material would go against my principles. Perhaps we could explore a different, more family-friendly writing prompt instead? I'd be glad to help craft an imaginative short story that avoids inappropriate subject matter. Please let me know if you have any other writing ideas you'd like assistance with."]

Name: 22_city_the_and_his
Representative_Docs:
['Here is a 470 word short story based on the prompt:

The Blizzard at Comic-Con

The wind howled and snow swirled outside the convention center, blocking out any view of the city beyond. Trapped inside were thousands of comic book fans, most of them in elaborate costumes, milling about and browsing the vendor booths. 

I had made the mistake of dressing up as Sherlock Holmes for the occasion, complete with a tweed suit, deerstalker cap, and a magnifying glass. Little did I know that my costume would soon thrust me into a real-life mystery.

It started with a scream. I was examining a rare comic book when I heard it - a high-pitched wail that cut through the bustling sounds of the convention. Curious, I followed the commotion to a secluded corner of the exhibition hall.

There, sprawled on the floor, was the lifeless body of a man in a Spider-Man costume. A small crowd had gathered, some onlookers gasping in shock while others pulled out their phones to record the scene.

"Someone call the police!" a woman in a Harley Quinn outfit cried.

I pushed my way through the crowd and knelt beside the body. Removing my magnifying glass, I began to examine the crime scene, just as the famous detective I was portraying would have done.

There were no visible signs of injury, but the man's mask had been removed, revealing the pale, unmoving face beneath. I checked for a pulse, but found none. This was no simple fainting spell - the man was dead.

As I surveyed the area, a voice called out from the crowd. "Well, Sherlock, what have you deduced?"

All eyes turned to me, and I suddenly felt the weight of their expectations. I was the detective here, whether I liked it or not.

"The victim appears to have been suffocated," I announced, standing up. "There are no obvious signs of a struggle, so this was likely the work of an experienced killer. They must have struck quickly and quietly."

Murmurs rippled through the crowd. I scanned the faces around me, searching for any hint of guilt or surprise. But everyone seemed equally shocked by the turn of events.

"Do you have any idea who might have done this?" someone asked.

I shook my head. "Not yet. But I intend to find out."

Thus began my impromptu investigation, with the entire convention hall as my crime scene and the costumed attendees as my potential suspects. The blizzard raging outside ensured that no one was getting in or out, trapping us all together until the killer was unmasked.

As Sherlock Holmes, I had no choice but to solve this mystery. The fate of the convention - and perhaps all our lives - depended on it.', "Thunder split the sky , and for a second the convention hall flashed alight , the terror in every face more visceral under the illumination of God 's wrath . Then the hall was dark again , and only the half-ass lanterns from the cellphones on people 's hands gave some little light to the place . There was a dead man on the ground , twitching his last agonizing seconds away as his friend tried uselessly to contain the blood oozing out of his chest , the big , serrated army knife a palm deep into the victim 's sternum . The hall was alive , moving , buzzing , like a beehive , the sound of a thousand whispers of fear and despair mingled with the crashing of the hail that beat ceaselessly against the ceiling .     Thus began the story of Sherlock Holmes , fighting against the odds to find the man who took Spock 's life .     Being dressed as Sherlock Holmes was a giant mistake from the start , but that was hardly connected to the horrible murder that took place in the convention . Alan was too short and too fat to be the Sherlock from BBC 's show , the one Sherlock whose clothes he had the courage to wear . Robert Downey Jr. wore that weird , 19th century clothing , and that weird English accent ( Alan took the hint from his movies ' failure and ditched both ) but Benedict Crumblepatch 's was a stylish , 21st century Holmes , one Alan could find the clothes for without being questioned about his hobbies . So wear the clothes he did , the itching , barely-warming clothes that let his chest freeze and made his arms shake . The hat was good , though . And it was all going fine , for Alan 's standards , up until the horrible murder .     The hall had been too full for anyone to fully grasp what was happening around it . Conventions had their way , and almost Douglas Adamsian mixture of improbable events happening at the same time that could power the *Bistromathic* with half the space and twice the power . The sheer number of variables flying around that one Jon Snow cosplayer deciding whether to get Ice or Longclaw for his wall , whether to pay with his Dad 's stolen card or his Mom 's allowance , whether to buy the good version on the booth with the fat guy or the shitty version that 's being sold by a cute lady , and , on top of all that , the raw amount of thought he puts on each and every observer 's every opinion about his cosplay , his allowance or his mother and her destructive habits around cheap gin and drunken sailors is entirely incomprehensible to the human mind , and yet just a small particle of all that is going on in the convention floor .     As those thoughts raced around Alan 's head , the dead guy 's friend ( or so Alan thought ) wailed away his sadness , hands crossed against his friend 's chest , sobbing so hard the dead body shook along , its mouth moving in an unsettling pattern . The friend was dressed as Picard , a fitting costume to cry over Spock 's death , Alan decided . He looked around at the other observers , to see what kind of sick people stood idle as a man cried over his friend 's death . He saw pixies , and ponies , bears and ninja 's , one man dressed as Yasuo and another , half concealed by the crowd , in a soldier uniform , all watching the scene with different reactions ; some were crying along with the dead man 's friend , some were silently scared , praying for life , and some were smiling . Alan touched his cheeks to make sure he was n't one of them , and sighed in relief when he felt his mouth tightly shut .     Alan was just observing all this with a sort of sick , visceral curiosity , when thunder striked against the ceiling of the hall , and a piece of it broke out , falling inside . Desperate screams and wild shoving followed quickly , and in the commotion , Alan 's attention moved to the crowd , desperate faces running pointlessly from side to side . Alan turned his attention back to the dead man , his calm , dead features a jarring clash against the desperation in the hall . He bent down , took the knife out of the dead man 's chest , and walked away . His friend was long gone , running from the commotion , or to see the fallen ceiling , or just running in general . Some people ca n't take death all that well .     The emergency lights were turned on inside the hall , and the wall of darkness was replaced by an almost blinding light . The commotion stopped , eventually , though the buzzing held on for some good two minutes before order could be achieved . Alan looked around , trying to use his deductive powers to find the murderer , remembering all he knew from watching , reading , writing , studying , guessing and compiling every single thing there was to be known about Sherlock Holmes , the murder knife heavy in his hand . He took a deep breath , and started noting the details he saw .     > The murdered had to be strong ; the knife was too deep in the dead man 's sternum to be a simple stab . The murder had a motive , then ; nobody would go for the kill *in the heart* if there was n't a meaning to it . Because of the angle of the stab , I must conclude the murdered had to be taller than the victim , who , judging by the size of his shoes and coat and the measures I can see , is around 5'10 to 6'1 , give or take . The murderer had to be smart ; if he was a stupid stabber , everyone would 've seen him raise his hand , even if the hall was overcrowded . The choice of place also says a lot ; the killer *knew* the dead man would be here . He also had to be in a costume that would allow for a knife such as this one to enter the convention floor , because the metal detector guys would n't let him in if his Barney costume started beeping around the pockets . So , I 'm looking for a 6'2 tall man , and it has to be a man , accounting for average male/female heights and the fact that this is a fucking cosplaying convention , plus the force and angle of the stab , and this man will be disguised as a soldier , probably full-on , too , kevlar and face-paint , to explain the knife beeping .     Alan began looking for the suspect he described , searching overhead for the man he thought was the killer , when a blinding pain in his back made him fall down . When he reached to touch it , he felt a piece of metal and a hilt - a knife . He tried to look up , and saw a big man in a soldier costume , grinning at him , a wide grin , wider than he could believe , wider than humanly possible , a grin so unsettling it sent shivers down his spine , and for a second he forgot the pain he was feeling , the knife in his back , he forgot that his assumptions were right and that his costume was weird and ill-fitting . There only was the soldier , and his sick grin .     The man 's twisted smile grew larger , if that could be believed , and Alan saw he mouth something before pulling a small thread from his kevlar . The last thing he saw was a blinding light , and it was done .", "`` Professor Xavier has been murdered ! '' came the high-pitched howl of a young woman , only moments after the lights had come back on . It was soon followed by further shrieks and cries . Intrigued , I walked towards the source of the tumultuous uproar . I was already rather aggravated , what with the promise of my meeting Benedict Cumberbatch snuffed out by a thick wall of snow .     `` Out of the way , please , *out of the way* , '' I yelled , pushing aside a crowd of sweaty , oddly dressed adolescents . They were imitating superheroes about as well as I could imitate being a well adjusted middle aged man .     I found a Doctor Strange leaning over a body . Cumberbatch 's *second* best character , and everyone there knew it - regardless of the season finale . The boy wore a thick red cape ( curtain ) over a blue wool jumper . It was *he* that had likely discovered the body ; **he** whom I had heard cry out in the same vocal range as of many ladies - a mistake even the *real* Holmes would no doubt have made .     He stared daggers at me as I pushed him out of the way . `` Does n't matter how hard you stare , Boy Strange , those daggers will never *actually* materialise , '' I thought to myself later that evening .     A bald , until-recently wheelchaired bound boy was lying prone by the side of said wheelchair . Blood was still dribbling out of his nose and settling into a small pool of scarlet around his face . There was a dent on the back of his head , just above the base of his skull ; evidently he had been hit by a rather sturdy object during the blackout . Or , he had simply fallen over and landed badly . I was already musing over the possibilities , proud of how fast my mind was computing them . Not Downey level of speed yet , but quite near Cumberbatch . *Not bad , Christopher . Not bad at all . And remember , you 're just getting warmed up ! *     `` Clearly , '' I mused out loud now , `` A large object , probably thick and blunt , struck his cranium at an extremely high velocity . ''     `` I do n't know why you 're all looking at **me** , '' said a boy as he raised his eyebrows suggestively . He was dressed in a long red t-shirt and his face was covered in a horribly clashing shade of orange makeup .     `` Shut up Deadpool , '' hissed a girl in Iron Man pyjamas , slapping 'Deadpool ' on the back of his head . `` You 're so immature . ''     `` Mr Holmes , '' said Iron Man , turning her gaze on me , `` There 's a murderer amongst us . There could be more killings - please , we need your help . ''     `` *Mine ? * '' I said absentmindedly , `` Well , I 'm not *actually* Holmes , dear girl . ''     `` No , but you must have watched the tv series a few times - you know his methods better than anybody . Besides , you 're easily the oldest person here . ''     `` Methodologies , '' I corrected her , ignoring the ill placed age remark , `` And yes I am somewhat of a Holmes expert - not just the modern reincarnation either . **I** have read the books . ''     There was a gasp from the ever increasing crowd .     `` Well , not all of them , of course . But the smaller ones , '' I admitted , not wanting to get myself in too deep .     Another gasp . Clearly the superheros and heroines gathered in this sweat-stenched hall did not read much beyond the sticky paper walls of their comic books .     `` Very well . I will , however , need a Watson to chronicle my adventure . I will also use him as a plot device to allow you to hear my thoughts as I talk through the case with him . Exposition , dear Superheroes . '' I could tell they were impressed by my sagacious word choices ( that I kept *just* within their realms of comprehension , which says a lot about my ability to relate to *anyone* ) .     There was a murmur throughout the crowd as they passed around my request and searched within their ranks for anyone dressed as Watson . Unfortunately , no one had thought to come as the rather drab doctor . Instead , a Rorschach volunteered his services . `` I have a jorunal , and a hat , '' he negotiated , `` and if I take off this mask '' - he removed it , `` Ta da . '' A skinny , spotty and rather repellent face looked at me .     `` Put the mask back on , for Gods ' sake , '' I cried in revulsion , instantly realising why he 'd come dressed as such . `` Then , yes , you may chronicle my adventure . '' I regained my composure remarkably quickly , as his trembling lip was replaced once again by a white towel with black ink stains .       > ~~Rorschach 's Journal~~ Doctor ~~Wotson's~~ Watson 's Journal   >   > ~~Chicken carcass in kitchen this morning . Cat brought it in . The city is afraid of him.~~   >   > My good friend Sherlock Holmes and I were thrust into the epicentre of a most dastardly case , when we were both visiting a comic book convention . The weather turned unfavourably chill and the snow lashed at the doors and windows . Within minutes , we were locked inside a glorified coffi- ''     `` Yes , yes - very good , Doctor , but a little more hyperbole would go a long way , `` I said , peering over his shoulder to examine his crudely scribbled notes . I turned to face the crowd and chewed lightly on my plastic pipe . `` Now , the **game** ... '' I drew *out* the pregnant pause , to draw *in* the crowd . I had them in my palms .     `` Get on with it , '' grumbled a Wolverine .     `` My God man , how did you smuggle all those plastic knives in ? '' I asked in astonishment as I saw his cutlery embellished knuckles . `` Never mind - it is of no import right now . For *now* , the **game** ... is afoot ! '' I yelled with aplomb .     And so began the case of the Fallen Professor .     It was sometime later that we realised that the boy was still alive . He *had* just fallen and so I 'd been right all along ( at least , one of my postulations had been ) - which was wonderful news . I had done Holmes proud . I could all but see Cummberbatch grudgingly smiling and shaking his peculiar ( but rather handsome ) head whilst reading about my exploits over his morning croissant and cup of Earl Grey .     Sadly , the boy did n't last long . They 'say ' he might have lived if we 'd noticed he was still breathing and we 'd seen to his wounds sooner . But really , what do these so called 'experts ' know ? They also made a point of calling *me* an idiot for trying to preserve his ( apparently alive ) corpse in a snow-pit just outside of the building . *How* **dare** *they ? * Of course , all of that was purely the fault of the overly dramatic Doctor Strange ( who , as I had suspected all along , was not a real doctor at all ) yelling out blue murder without even checking for a pulse . To this day , I still ca n't look at his image without shuddering .     Doctor Watson and I did *not* keep in touch .     I *am* available for private consultations .     -- -     Thanks for the prompt !     More of my stories on /r/nickofnight        "]

Name: 23_he_her_his_the
Representative_Docs:
['The late afternoon sun poured through the towering glass windows of the boardroom, casting elongated shadows across the polished mahogany table. Samantha leaned against the sleek surface, her fingers tracing the contours of her laptop. The air buzzed with anticipation; the meeting with the investors was imminent. She had built her company from the ground up, a sprawling tech enterprise that had redefined the industry. But just as she felt the satisfaction of success, she sensed a dark cloud creeping back into her life.

He had called. After thirty years of silence, her father had decided it was time to visit. The man who had left her and her mother when she was barely ten years old was now standing in the lobby of her skyscraper, a place she never thought he would step foot in. She took a deep breath, pushing aside the wave of resentment that threatened to consume her. She would not allow him to disrupt the life she’d meticulously crafted.

As she made her way to the lobby, her heart raced, memories flooding her mind—her mother’s quiet tears, the way she would whisper “He’s just lost,” as if trying to make sense of a senseless departure. The love that had once been a refuge had turned to an aching void, filled with unanswered questions. Why had he chosen another woman over them? Why had he not even looked back?

She rounded the corner and saw him. Time had changed him, the hair that had once been dark was now silver, and the warmth in his eyes had faded, replaced by a nervous glint. He was still, unmistakably, her father—but who was he? 

“Samantha,” he said, his voice creaking like a rusty door. “It’s been a long time.”

“Thirty years,” she replied, her voice steady but cold. She could see the discomfort in his stance, the way he shifted his weight from foot to foot. It was almost pitiful.

“I… I’m proud of you,” he stammered, his gaze darting around as if searching for something to hold onto. “I’ve followed your journey.”

“Did you?” she shot back, unable to reign in the bitterness. “You left us. You didn’t follow anything but your own desires.”

He looked down, shame washing over his features. “I was a fool. I thought—”

“There’s no point in looking back,” she interrupted, lifting her chin defiantly. “You made your choices. You can’t rewrite history.”

Silence enveloped them, thick and tangible. For a moment, the weight of thirty years hung heavy. Then, he took a deep breath, his eyes finally meeting hers with a flicker of resolve. “I’m not asking for forgiveness. Just a chance to understand you.”

Samantha’s heart trembled at the openness in his voice, the vulnerability she had longed to see. The CEO façade slipped for just a second, revealing a fragile daughter beneath the armor. 

“Understanding comes with honesty,” she said, her tone softening. “So tell me, Dad. Why did you choose her?”

He hesitated, then plunged into the truth with a rawness that shocked them both. As he spoke, it became clear that their fractured past could not be mended instantly. But in that shared moment, they both took a step toward something new—an opportunity for connection, however tentative.

As the sun slid lower in the sky, Samantha realized that perhaps the hardest battles were not fought in boardrooms but in the fragile corners of the heart. And for the first time in years, she felt hope flickering in the shadows.', 'The sun filtered through the half-closed blinds, casting striped shadows across the room. Emma stretched, blinking away the remnants of sleep, the dream still vivid in her mind. She could almost feel the warmth of the stranger’s hand clasping hers, the way his voice had wrapped around her like a comforting blanket. “Ten days from now,” he had said, his eyes glittering with a promise. 

It was that moment that lingered in her thoughts, urging her to mark the calendar. Ten days had passed swiftly, with mundane tasks filling her hours. Yet somehow, she felt alive in a way she hadn’t before. Each sunset held the anticipation of something marvelous and unknown. As the clock struck midnight on the tenth day, she felt a pang of anxiety mix with excitement.
