The Pre-Crime Scan might have been wrong about her, but it had inadvertently shown her the power of her own choices. And that, she realized, was the most valuable lesson of all.
']

Name: 31_god_peter_heaven_the
Representative_Docs:
["I 'll admit it , I was drunk when I got the idea . It was late at night in my plush apartment , and I was sitting naked on the couch watching infomercials on TV while scrolling absentmindedly through my phone . I had just finished the last of the gin when the ad for the latest miracle cleaning product ended , and a televangelist came on . He started spewing the same holy roller crap they all do , and as he started quoting scripture , I idly thought , `` Whoever wrote this stuff is out a lot of money for everyone copying his stuff . ''     I passed out on the couch after that , but had some weirdly vivid dreams of being in court with Pope Francis on the witness stand . I woke up with a massive hangover and an idea that just would n't leave . It was ridiculous , and utterly without basis in law . But it would be the perfect way to embarrass all those religious nuts out there : have God sue the Catholic Church for copyright infringement .     The twisted beauty of it was not the idea of getting the Catholic Church to shell out a fat stack of cash for actual copyright violations . No , it was forcing them to defend against a perfectly worded complaint . The easy way to defeat a copyright claim was to say that the subject was public domain - which under U.S. law happens 75 years after the author 's death . Was the Catholic Church prepared to say God had been dead for 75 years ? Another defense is that the plaintiff is n't the actual author or holder of the copyright . Was the Catholic Church prepared to admit that God did n't write the Bible ?     So I found a bum on the street who said he was God himself , and filed the complaint . Most of my partners were pissed . Some were a bit more religious than I had known , and some were just mad that I was wasting my time on this . But the partners that , like me , did n't believe , were confused at first . They asked me why I was representing God . But when I explained my mission , and showed them my complaint , they got on board . Suddenly , I had a full legal team ready to prosecute God 's rights .     The media outlets did n't pay our case much attention until the Catholic Church filed its answer to our complaint . I had been expecting a full legal smack down , tearing our claims to shreds . Instead , they admitted everything . God was the original author of the Bible , the Catholic Church had been copying his work , and that they had not paid any valid consideration for the right to do so . The church asserted just one defense : `` There is no copyright on fundamental truth . ''     My legal team and I were stunned . Through their admissions , we had gone from having no case to having an almost too perfect case . All we had to do was defeat their defense , and we could collect billions from the Catholic Church .     Trial came unusually quickly . The church did n't bother filing any motions , and we wanted our day in court . Getting there proved to be a challenge in itself . The area around the courthouse was choked with protesters . Our case had struck a cord with across the country , with protesters from every state coming to denounce us as heathens , or to protest the other protesters and make fun of religion . Obviously , my sympathies lay with one side of the protest , and not with the other .     When I finally made it inside the courtroom , my client was waiting for me at counsel 's table . I breathed a sigh of relief : he had listened to my instructions and gotten himself cleaned up .     `` Lord , '' I said , patting him on the shoulder . `` How are you ? ''     `` Nervous , man . Nervous . This is all quite a production . ''     `` Yeah , this became quite something , did n't it ? ''     God did n't have a chance to answer , as the doors to the courtroom snapped open . In walked the lawyer for the Catholic Church , and trailing behind him was Pope Francis himself .     `` Ho-ly shit , '' God said , emphasizing each syllable . `` They brought out the big guns . ''     I smirked . They were certainly trying to put on a show . `` No gun 's bigger than you , right Lord ? '' I looked over at my client , and he gave a nervous nod .     `` All rise ! '' the bailiff shouted , quieting the room . A small door in the back of the courtroom snapped open , and the judge took the bench . The bailiff continued , `` The United States District Court for the District of New York is now in session . Judge Houston Garrison presiding . God bless the United States and this honorable tribunal . ''     `` Objection , '' I said , standing . `` Hearsay , your honor . God is present in the courtroom with us today . I 'd ask that court staff refrain from putting words in his mouth . ''     Judge Garrison rolled his eyes . `` Overruled , '' he grumbled . `` I hope you are n't under the illusion that antics like those will be scoring you points with me , Mr . Fine . ''     `` No Your Honor , '' I responded , and sat down .     `` For the record , we 're here on case seven dash one six five three seven , God versus the Catholic Church , '' Judge Garrison continued . `` Are there any pretrial motions ? ''     `` No Your Honor , '' I answered .     The lawyer for the church , Luke Howard , stood . He was a surprisingly young looking man , and this would be his opportunity to start undermining our case by asking the court to limit the evidence we could introduce during the trial . I had a stack of case law in front of me ready to rebut whatever motions he would make . `` No , Your Honor . Nothing for the defendant , '' he said , his voice filled with a quiet authority .     Judge Garrison squinted at Howard , as if trying to see if the lawyer was having some kind of stroke . `` Very well , '' Judge Garrison said finally . `` Then let 's get going on jury selection . ''     This was going to be a very unusual case .     *****     You can read more of my prompt responses by subscribing to [ Pubby 's Creative Workshop ] ( https : //www.reddit.com/r/Pubby88 ) . Now with a [ Part II ] ( https : //www.reddit.com/r/Pubby88/comments/5ww81i/you_are_representing_pope_francis_in_the_case_of/dee1fbl/ ? st=izrkrdu6 & sh=e18c1798 ) !", 'Here is a short story based on the prompt:

The Forgotten Meeting

After spending decades in the peaceful serenity of Heaven, I finally mustered up the courage to request an audience with the Almighty. I had so many questions that had been weighing on my mind, and I yearned for the opportunity to speak directly with God. 

I approached the pearly gates, where the ever-diligent St. Peter stood guard. "Excuse me, Peter," I said nervously. "I was hoping to have a meeting with the Lord. Is that possible?"

Peter eyed me curiously. "A meeting with God, you say?" He paused, his brow furrowing. "Well, I'm afraid that won't be possible."

"What do you mean?" I asked, my heart sinking. "Surely He is still here, in Heaven, is He not?"

Peter sighed heavily. "I'm afraid not. God left a very long time ago."

I stared at him in disbelief. "Left? What do you mean, left? Where did He go?"

"I'm not entirely sure," Peter admitted. "One day, He just...disappeared. Vanished without a trace. We've been trying to carry on in His absence, but it's been a great challenge. The angels have been running things as best they can, but it's not the same without our Creator here."

"But...how can that be?" I stammered. "God can't just leave Heaven! This is His domain, His kingdom! Where would He have gone?"

Peter shook his head solemnly. "I wish I knew, my friend. All I can tell you is that He's been gone for decades now. No one has seen or heard from Him since. It's as if He's simply...forgotten about us."

I felt a deep ache in my chest. The idea of God abandoning His heavenly realm was almost too much to bear. All this time, I had been longing for a chance to speak with Him, to gain wisdom and clarity. And now, that opportunity had slipped through my fingers.

"Is there no way to find Him?" I pleaded. "Surely there must be something we can do!"

Peter gave me a sympathetic look. "I'm afraid not. We've sent out search parties, scoured the cosmos, but there's been no sign of Him. It's as if He's simply...disappeared."

I stood there, stunned, my mind racing. How could this be happening? What could have possibly compelled God to abandon His beloved Heaven and its inhabitants? The more I thought about it, the more distraught I became.

"I'm sorry, my friend," Peter said, placing a hand on my shoulder. "I know this is difficult news to hear. But we must carry on, and trust that God will return to us when the time is right."

As I turned and walked away, I couldn't help but feel a deep sense of sorrow and uncertainty. The world I had known, the certainties I had always taken for granted, had been shattered. And now, I was left to grapple with the unsettling reality that even the Almighty was not immune to the mysteries of the universe.', "`` Here 's the thing ... '' Peter began . He cleared his throat and glanced at the never-ending line of recently deceased that waited to find out if they were allowed through the turn-style , getting their hand stamped in the process , or if they would be directed towards the Slide , complete with a sign saying `` You Must Have Sinned This Much To Ride '' . Peter figured they could wait for a few minutes . Some were going to relish this last bit of torment-free existence , and the others would be in Paradise so it would n't matter . Peter stepped from behind his podium and put his arm around my shoulder , walking me to the edge of the cloud and looking down .     `` You see Fred ... God has been here a long time . And I mean , a LONG time . That whole Creation thing ? Yeah ... That was well into His stay . It 's like an apartment . You get bored with the same old , same old , and then you bring in new furniture . So imagine how long He was here before He got bored enough to create the universe .     `` Anyways , He decided that watching the mortals was n't cutting it for entertainment anymore . He decided that it was dumb of Him to create the whole universe and not go see how it was doing . So He packed his bags and took off , leaving JC in charge . ''     I stood there and blinked a few times , realization dawning on me . Jesus , or JC as Peter called him , walked among the streets of Heaven , glad-handing and kissing babies , the eternal politician . But whenever someone started to get too smart , started to figure things out , Jesus would inevitably say that `` Father is beckoning me '' and He would disappear for awhile .     Now I realize that all those times Jesus was just taking a coffee break . `` Checking the back room '' as retail workers called it , or `` asking a manager '' if you had been a car salesman .     I 'm not begrudging God anything . I mean , Heaven kind of runs itself . There 's angels everywhere , and some of them are probably just as bored watching us mortals as God was .     But anyways , back to the conversation with Peter . I 'm standing on the edge of the cloud , looking down at the expanse of humanity , and finding it dull myself . I mean , I lived it for 47 years before that damn truck took me out . I know all about the hate of the alarm clock buzzing , the taste of toothpaste and orange juice , the boss in your ear and the cold dinner at home and the routine of doing it over and over . I could only sympathize with God for becoming bored of it after seeing countless generations do it .     I stood there looking down still . Peter gave me a pat on the shoulder as he saw I understood , and he went back to the podium . I stood there , watching humanity , and I began to feel jealous . I was jealous of God and His ability to just pack up and go . I want to see stars being born and exploding , damnit ! I want to see eruptions on distant planets , observe alien species doing alien things ! I want to ride a comet as it crashes into the side of a moon , obliterating both of them and creating asteroids and meteors . If only I could ...     I turned back to Peter and he just looked at me and smiled , nodding once . At that moment a completely new feeling came over me . All at once I understood everything I ever wanted to understand . I could feel not only the cloud beneath my feet but also the air it rested on , how it shifted like sand in a lake bad as people moved . Peter knew what had happened , and after a split second of confusion I understood as well .     I had broken free of the last chains that held my spirit . I was no longer dead Fred . I had truly , after decades here , accepted all that Heaven was and finally began to think outside the bounds that a lifetime of humanity had imposed upon me . I had the biggest shit-eating grin on my face as Peter laughed a bit .     `` It never gets old watching this , '' he said . He picked up his quill and called for the next waiting soul to step forward . I quickly made my way back towards the gates , pausing a moment to thank Peter for his time when he grabbed my arm gently but firmly and whispered into my ear .     `` Each person must come to understand this on their own . When they are ready , they will make that transition . Go , enjoy yourself . We 'll still be here when you get back . '' With that he gave me a kiss on the forehead , like an uncle would , and turned back to his duty . I felt a momentary pang of pity for him , being shackled to that podium until the Second Coming . He must have sensed this , because he looked back at me and winked before mouthing `` Go , it 's ok '' .     I hurried inside and up to my apartment , scribbling a note and hanging it from my door . I paused and thought how much Heaven was laid out like a giant college campus , with dorms and lecture halls , before laughing and heading back towards the gates . I felt more alive than I had when I was alive , and I was excited beyond words to watch Jupiter 's storms churn and roil in the atmosphere .     As I stepped out off the cloud and willed my spirit towards the blackness of space , I understood now what people had told me my whole life , about Heaven being what you made it to be . I chuckled and headed for the Asteroid Belt , thinking that God and I would have something to talk about other than historical events should we ever meet up . And if we did n't , that was OK too . Afterall , this was His Heaven too ."]

Name: 32_detective_he_his_the
Representative_Docs:
['Here is a short story based on the prompt:

The Paperwork

Sarah stared down at the stack of forms in front of her, her hands trembling slightly. She couldn't believe she was actually doing this - going through with the legal process to commit murder. But after everything that had happened, she felt she had no other choice.

It had started a year ago, when her husband, Mark, had been killed in a hit-and-run accident. The police had never been able to find the driver responsible, and Sarah was left devastated and alone. The grief had been overwhelming, and she had spiraled into a deep depression, barely able to function.

Then, a few months ago, she had learned the shocking truth - the hit-and-run was no accident. It had been intentional, a calculated murder. And the person responsible was Mark's business partner, James.

Sarah had been outraged, her grief turning to rage. She had confronted James, demanding to know why he had killed her husband. His confession had been chilling - he had been embezzling money from their company, and Mark had found out. Rather than risk getting caught, James had decided to eliminate the problem.

Sarah had gone to the police, but they had told her that without solid evidence, there was nothing they could do. That's when she had discovered the new law - the "Murder Permit" as it was called. For a hefty fee and a mountain of paperwork, a person could legally commit murder, as long as the intended victim was given 30 days' notice.

As Sarah filled out the forms, her mind raced. She knew that what she was doing was wrong, that it went against everything she believed in. But the thought of James getting away with Mark's murder was too much to bear. She had to do this, for Mark's sake.

With a heavy heart, she signed the last form and submitted the paperwork. Now all she could do was wait.

The 30 days passed in a blur, and Sarah found herself standing outside James' home, a gun trembling in her hand. She had agonized over this moment, wondering if she could really go through with it. But then she thought of Mark, and her resolve hardened.

As James stepped outside, she raised the gun and pulled the trigger. The shot rang out, and James crumpled to the ground, his life snuffed out in an instant.

Sarah stood there, staring at the lifeless body, tears streaming down her face. She had done it - she had committed murder, legally. But the weight of what she had done was crushing, and she knew that no matter what, she would never be the same again.', '“ Another day , another arrival of Fresh meat. ” Butch said as he tightly gripped my shoulder . As the tips of his fingers forcefully kneaded away at my muscle , I thought the same though I had every morning the new arrivals showed up . How could being in the wrong place at the wrong time put me here ?     It had become ritual here , watching the “ originals ” file in , whooping at them in the way you see in movies . Crime had become an unseen evil , ever since the cloning initiative had taken place . Brilliant if you think about it , if nobody ever “ goes ” to jail , who knows that there are any crimes taking place ? The criminals knew of course . But their replacements were conditioned well enough to keep the flow of society moving . Murderous Fathers went home to their children . It isn ’ t even to say they ’ re in short supply though , the criminals . It ’ s all another smoke and mirrors thing . Like diet soda .     As my cell-mate drives his pelvis into my back , pushing me up against the bars to “ show ” the new crop of degenerates what they ’ re in for , an officer hits the bars ,   making his presence known .     “ Ay , Butch . Put it back in your pants . Warden wants this one. ”     I slide out through the open bars , not giving a second though as to why the warden wants to see me . I ’ ve heard it before , guys being escorted out to see the warden , but I ’ d never figured out why . Things were pretty tight here .     The guard , whose badge reads Smith , silently pushes his baton into my spine . “ This way bud. ” As I ’ m prodded away from the new recruits . “ Warden needs to see you now , or it ’ s my ass that ’ ll be getting the Butch treatment .   “ So , Smith… ” I ask keeping my eyes forward for fear of another pound of force between my vertebrae “ … did the Warden say why he needed me ? ” Smith didn ’ t break his gait , his obedient pace keeping time . “ Warden took a look at the manifest and sent me to you . That ’ s all you need to know. ” Our time together was coming to a close . Something about this walk was familiar , and I felt it was almost over .     The large ornate door was before us at the end of the march . It ’ s frame , a beautifully stained and treated Oak , the handles brass with a bold golden embellishment . Stark , silver letters on the top read “ Scientia et Silentium illius pacificae ” . Something about it is hauntingly familiar . A real different feel from the rest of this place . That medicinal pallid blue coating the walls , with the occasional sliding steel doors created a real feeling of warmth and hospitality . Seemingly un-aided , the door opened outward . Smith and I stepped inside .     Sitting behind a large Oak desk , no doubt purposefully matching the door to its opposite sat a finely dressed man , thinning up top and a bit rounder about the face than average . Around him were set a number of plaques , trophies , certificates and other accolades given form . “ You can go Smith. ” The man said , in a soft and slight falsetto . Smith , as dutiful as ever , silently nodded as he sheathed his club turning to leave . His footsteps were made as silent as his gesture by the lush olive carpet beneath . “ Mister…oh who are we kidding here . Let ’ s do away with such formalities ” he chuckled to himself as an unsettling smile crept across his wide face . “ It ’ s Rod , right ? Rodney Ballick ? Oh Rod , it warms the cockles of my clogged arteries to see you again . We had a running bet , and here you are again ! Looks like this old dog gets another bone. ” He begins to chuckle and bow his head .     I wonder to myself who this asshole thinks he is . How does he know…Rod is what my “ ….mother used to call me ? ” he says , as his teeth explode from behind his lips , revealing a self-assured shit eating grin . “ You know , you said that maybe two times ago ? ” What the hell…how did he… ” Listen Rodney , we could do this ad-nauseum , but I ’ m going to let you in on a little secret. ” He gets up , checking his reflection in one of the many reflective surfaces lining his office . “ You are home to one of the laughably most unlucky set of genes in modern history , my friend. ” My stomach turns , as I desperately try to make sense of what he ’ s saying . He straightens his tie , musses his hair and makes for a Lab Coat , hanging in the corner of the room . “ It ’ s not as simple as it was 20 years ago , when I was in corrections , Rod ” he furrows his brow , confiding in me like we ’ re old friends . “ Ever since this whole cloning business started , well , let ’ s just say repeat offenders are the real bear of running a prison. ” He places his hand onto one of the plaques adorning the room , which causes the floor of the room to sink .   The ride down is mostly silent . For me anyways . My mind and stomach are running circles around each other , getting worse with each pass . The Warden continues on , about the energy shortage , science fiction and crisis management .     We hit the obvious bottom with a light shake , only to be greeted by the exact same ornate doors . “ Funny isn ’ t it , these damn doors seem to be everywhere important. ” They open , inward to a large annex . A long , white hallway , seemingly coated in linoleum with a sickeningly sterile scent in the air . The warden forcefully locked arms with me . “ Now Rodney , as I had mentioned earlier , repeat offenders were a problem when we first started here… ” he prattled on , moving me like a parent moves their child down the hallway . I gave little resistance , but my legs weren ’ t responding as actively as I had liked . Instead , my focus was on the doors that lined the hallway . Each one , marked with a different name than the last . “ …the skeptics say its coincidence , while the mystics prattle on about destiny…in my experience ” his tone becoming more and more droning as we proceed forward . “ …until ” He cuts short . “ Ah , here we are . See the name on this door Rod ? ” I did .     Bold , black letters read Rodney J. Ballick . “ Do you know why you ’ re here this time ? ” The warden ’ s arm untangling itself with mine , as his fingertips found my shoulder . “ It was eavesdropping . There are non-violent felonies , Rod , and your rap sheet lists like a textbook on them. ” The door opened inward , and inside were capsules , large enough to fit , well…me .     As the tips of his fingers forcefully kneaded away at my muscle , he continued “ First , you accidentally got stuck in traffic caused by a religious gathering . You just happened to be the one charged with disrupting a religious gathering in the first. ” Caught completely unaware , two large men appeared at my side , fastening me into restraints . “ The other times , well let ’ s just say , you were a great way to hone the process we used to deal with…repeat offenders. ”     The last thing I saw before being submerged into the liquid was the warden wiping his brow as he let out a heaving sigh .  ', "I tried . Hope you enjoy .     -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -   -Hey Murdock , there 's one here for you .       That was my boss delivering on the promise he made to me . After my promotion , first suspect to show up would be mine to interrogate . I was ecstatic . I was naive .       -Follow me - said my boss , his triple chin jiggling - Complete nuts this one . Name of Sebastian Goodman . We found his wife dead on the basement after an anonymous call complaining about the smell .       -Well , that 's not that uncommon , sir - I said as we walked       -Yeah , you 're right , that 's unfortunately very common but the rest is n't . The walls were painted red with her blood . All her blood .       -What do you mean all her blood ? How ?       -Vacuum cleaner . Just sucked everything right up . Wrote some weird shit on the floor with the blood too .       We stop at the door of the interrogation room .       -Anything else I need to know , sir ?       -Basement full of candles , book fill of creepy drawings on a table , her body was in the middle of a spiral . Sacrifice , it seems . But we got ta question the bastard - he grins - And you 're just the man for it .       -Wo n't disappoint you , sir .       -I know you wo n't . Now , I 'll be on the other side of the glass and the guy is cuffed so no need to be nervous . He 's crazy but he is n't Superman and , even better , he did n't want a lawyer . So get in there and grab a confession .       With that , I 'm left alone by the door . I calm my nerves and get in .   Inside , sits the `` suspect '' , hands still dirty with crusted blood , but who , somehow , is wearing a completely clean black suit . It did n't fit him very well but the result was n't any less unsettling . His eyes bored into me as soon as I got in but I manage to keep eye contact even through my uneasiness .       I take my time to sit on the other chair , positioning my self in front of him .       -How are the girls , Detective Murdock ? - he blurts out .       I pale . How did he know my name ? What does he know about my daughters ?       -Fine , I shall not talk about your personal life while you have a job to do . Please , do question me .       Pulling myself together , I take a slow breath and feel the anger rising . Who the hell does this guy think he is ? Hannibal Lecter ? No no , he is n't going to play with my head .       -Mr. Goodman , did you murder your wife on the night of November 16th ?       -No , he did n't .       -What do you mean by he ? Did you murder your wife or not ?       -He killed her on the 15th . And it was around dusk so who can say if it was really night ?       Okay , the guy is definitely nuts , but I almost had the confession .       I press on - So you confess to the murder of Laura Goodman ?       -Yes . Mr Goodman did kill his wife . Strangled her . Cut her open like a pig , pulled her organs out and sucked the blood into the vacuum to use as paint . - he chuckles - Some people like going the extra mile when redecorating .       I get up . He 's so cold , composed . He 's enjoying himself and I 'm most definitely not . But I 'm curious , that 's why I wanted to be a detective . Always too damn good with the questions .       -Why did you do it ? - I ask against my better judgment       -He did it for power , of course . You promise people a way to step on others and , more often than not , they 'll want it . They 'll do anything for it . And so he did .       -What kind of power could you get from killing your wife ? That does n't make sense .       But in the back of my head , I know it does . I do n't want to believe it but it does .       -Please , help me ! - he screams , his voice suddenly different and desperate - I did n't want to do it , I tried to stop but it was too late ! Kill me and burn it ! You have to !       -Sir , calm down . Burn what ? I do n't understand       -The book , burn the - he becomes silent and his face changes back to its composed self - That wo n't happen again . But I must leave now , detective , as I 'm sure you must do too . Maggie and Sabrina miss you .       He gets up , snapping his cuffs almost as if in an afterthought .       -You stay where you are , do n't move an inch- I warn him , gun raised and aimed at his chest       -Please , detective , let 's be civil . There 's no need for threats .       He steps towards the door and , just as I 'm about to shoot him , my boss bursts in with another two officers .     -You stay right there , you freak , or I 'll blow your fucking brains out . Steve , cuff the fucker .       That 's when it happens . A moment that will haunt me for the rest of my life . Goodman just looked at me and my life went down the drain .       -Mr. Murdock , would you please take care of these men ?       My muscles tensed and I moved without wanting to . Then I blew the brains out of my three colleagues .       -Very well done , detective . Now I must depart . - And he starts walking casually towards the door .       My legs give way and I crumble to the floor , gun forgotten beside me .       -Who are you ? - I whisper       He turns back to look at me .       -Mr. Goodman was a stupid selfish little man but the unwary pawns are often the best ones . The world wo n't miss him . Enjoy your life , detective , and do give a hug on the girls for me .         The girls live with her mother now , they do n't hug me anymore . Every cop in the country hates my guts and I ca n't even blame them . I 'm in an asylum . No one believes my story , of course . But I know what 's out there and I 'm gon na put it down ."]

Name: 33_my_wilderness_will_me
Representative_Docs:
['Here is a short story based on the prompt:

Day 1 of Exile

Today marks the first day of my exile into the wilderness. After being found guilty of a crime I did not commit, the council has sentenced me to 20 long years living alone in the untamed forest beyond our village. 

As I write this by the flickering light of my campfire, I can still hear the jeers and shouts of the villagers as they dragged me away. The look of triumph on the face of my accuser, the man who falsely testified against me, burns in my mind. I will never forgive him for this injustice.

The journey here was long and arduous. I was forced to march for days with my hands bound, allowed only meager rations and sips of water. By the time we reached the edge of the forest, my body ached and my spirit was nearly broken. 

Now, alone in the wilderness, I am filled with a mix of fear and determination. Fear of the unknown dangers that surely lurk in these woods - the predatory animals, the unforgiving elements, the possibility of never seeing civilization again. And determination to survive, to endure this punishment, and one day return to prove my innocence.

I have been left with only the clothes on my back, a small knife, and a pouch of seeds to plant a meager garden. The task of building a shelter, finding food and water, and defending myself seems insurmountable. But I have no choice. This is my new reality for the next 20 years.

I do not know what the future holds. But I vow to keep this diary, to record my struggles and triumphs, in the hopes that one day someone will find it and know my story. I will not give up. I will not let this unjust exile break me. I will survive.

Day 7,305 of Exile (20 years later)

Today is the final day of my exile. After 20 long years in the wilderness, I am finally being permitted to return to the village. 

As I sit by my campfire, now a seasoned and weathered man, I flip through the tattered pages of the diary I began on my first day here. So much has happened, so much I have endured. There were times I thought I would not make it, that the elements or wild animals would claim me. But I persevered.

I built a sturdy log cabin, tended to my garden, and hunted small game to sustain myself. I weathered harsh winters, evaded predators, and nursed myself back to health after falls and injuries. There were dark days of loneliness and despair, but I never gave up hope.

And now, the day I have dreamed of for two decades is finally here. Tomorrow, I will make the long journey back to the village. I wonder how much it has changed in my absence. I wonder if the man who falsely accused me is still there, living freely while I suffered. I wonder if anyone will believe my story after all this time.

But I no longer fear the unknown. I have faced the wilderness and conquered it. I am a different man now, hardened by my experiences. I will return with my head held high, ready to reclaim my life and clear my name.

This diary has been my companion, my outlet, my connection to the world I was torn from. I will cherish it always. And I pray that somehow, someday, it will help me find the justice I have been denied for far too long.', 'Here is a short story based on the prompt:

Day 1 of Exile

Today is the first day of my exile in the wilderness. I have been banished from my village for the next 20 years as punishment for a crime I did not commit. The village elders accused me of stealing from the communal food stores, but I swear I am innocent. However, my pleas fell on deaf ears, and now I find myself alone in this vast, untamed landscape.

As I sit here writing by the flickering light of the fire, I am filled with a mix of emotions - fear, anger, and a deep sense of loneliness. The forest is an imposing and unforgiving place, teeming with unknown dangers. I have been provided with only the barest of supplies - a small sack of dried food, a flint for starting fires, and a knife. I must learn to survive on my own, to find shelter, hunt for food, and ward off any predators that may lurk in the shadows.

The uncertainty of the future weighs heavily on my mind. How will I endure 20 long years in this solitude? Will I ever see my family and friends again? I cannot help but wonder if I will even survive that long. 

As the fire crackles and the night creatures begin to stir, I find myself wishing I was back home, safe and warm in my bed. I miss the comfort of my village, the laughter of children, the familiar faces of my neighbors. Now I am utterly alone, with only the wilderness as my companion.

I will try to remain strong and persevere, but the road ahead seems impossibly long and daunting. I can only pray that I will find the will to carry on, day by day, until my exile is finally over.

Day 7,300 of Exile (Last Day)

Today marks the end of my 20-year exile in the wilderness. As I sit by the fire, my weathered hands tracing the worn pages of my journal, I am struck by the contrast between my first day here and this final one.

When I first arrived, I was filled with fear and uncertainty, unsure if I would even survive. The forest was a hostile, unforgiving place, and I struggled to adapt to the harsh realities of life alone in the wild. There were many times I doubted my ability to endure, when the loneliness and hardship threatened to consume me.

But over the years, I have learned to thrive in this environment. I have become one with the land, attuned to its rhythms and cycles. I have built sturdy shelters, mastered the art of hunting and foraging, and discovered inner reserves of strength and resilience I never knew I possessed.

The wilderness has been both my greatest challenge and my salvation. It has stripped away the distractions and comforts of my former life, forcing me to confront myself and my deepest fears. In the solitude, I have found a peace and clarity that eluded me before.

Now, as I prepare to return to my village, I feel a bittersweet mix of emotions. I am eager to see my loved ones again, to reconnect with the familiar sights and sounds of home. But I will also miss the tranquility and freedom of this place, the sense of being truly alive and in harmony with the natural world.

I have changed so much during these 20 years. The young, naive man I once was has been transformed by his experiences in the wilderness. I am wiser, more self-reliant, and more attuned to the essential rhythms of life. This exile has been a gift, a chance to rediscover myself and my place in the world.

As I gaze into the flickering flames, I know that a part of me will always remain here, in this sacred, wild place. It has become a part of me, just as I have become a part of it. And for that, I am eternally grateful.', "Here is a short story based on the prompt:

Day 1 - Exile Begins

Today is the day my exile begins. After being convicted of a crime I did not commit, the council has sentenced me to 20 years of solitude in the wilderness. As I stand at the edge of the forest, preparing to enter, a deep sense of dread fills me. I have never been beyond the borders of our village, and the thought of surviving on my own in the wild unknown fills me with fear. 

I carry only a small pack with the barest of supplies - a flint for starting fires, a knife, a water flask, and a bit of dried meat. The village elders tell me there is a small cabin deep in the woods where I can take shelter, but beyond that, I am on my own. No contact with the outside world, no chance to plead my case. Just 20 long years to contemplate my fate.

As I take my first steps into the forest, I can't help but look back at the life I'm leaving behind. My family, my friends, the comfortable routine I once took for granted. Now it all feels so distant, as if from another lifetime. I steel myself, knowing dwelling on the past will only make this harder. I must focus on survival, on making it through each day, one by one, until my sentence is complete.

The path ahead is overgrown and uneven. I stumble frequently, my legs unused to such rugged terrain. The dense canopy of trees blocks out much of the sunlight, casting an eerie shadow over everything. Every snap of a twig or rustle in the undergrowth has me jumping in alarm, my heart pounding. 

I press on, determined to reach the cabin before nightfall. As the sun begins to dip below the horizon, I finally spot the weathered structure in the distance. It's a meager dwelling, but the sight of it fills me with relief. At least I will have shelter from the elements.

I push open the creaking door and step inside, surveying my new home. It's sparse, with only a bed, a table, and a small fireplace. But it will have to do. As I start a fire and prepare a simple meal, I can't help but wonder what the next 20 years will hold. Will I go mad from the isolation? Or will I find a way to survive, even thrive, in this wilderness?

Only time will tell. For now, I must focus on the present, on making it through this first night. Tomorrow, the real test begins.

Day 7,300 - Exile Ends

Today is the day my exile ends. After 20 long years in the wilderness, I am finally free to return to the village. As I step out of the cabin and take a deep breath of the fresh air, I feel a mix of emotions - relief, trepidation, and a deep sense of nostalgia for the life I've built here.

When I first arrived, I was terrified, unsure if I would even survive. But over the years, I've learned to adapt, to thrive in this harsh environment. I've become self-sufficient, a skilled hunter and forager. I've found peace in the solitude, in the rhythms of nature that have become my companions.

In many ways, this place has become a home to me, more so than the village I left behind. The people there, the life I once knew, now feel like distant memories, almost like they belonged to a different person. I've changed so much, grown in ways I never could have imagined.

As I turn to take one last look at the cabin, I'm struck by a profound sense of gratitude. This place has been my refuge, my sanctuary. It has forced me to confront my deepest fears and insecurities, to find strength and resilience I never knew I possessed.

I don't know what awaits me back in the village. Will the people there even recognize me? Will they welcome me back, or will they still see me as the criminal I was once accused of being? I can't help but feel a twinge of anxiety at the thought of re-entering that world.

But as I begin the long journey back, I know that I am no longer the same man who left all those years ago. I am stronger, wiser, more at peace with myself. Whatever challenges lie ahead, I am ready to face them head-on.

This exile has been a trial by fire, but I have emerged from it forged anew. And for that, I am grateful."]

Name: 34_pizza_cheese_crust_he
Representative_Docs:
['Here is a short story based on the prompt:

It was a slow Friday night at Pete's Pizza, the local joint that was really just a front for the city's biggest cocaine distribution operation. The young cashier, Tommy, was manning the phone, half-heartedly answering the occasional call for a pizza delivery.

Suddenly, the phone rang. Tommy answered with his usual greeting, "Pete's Pizza, how can I help you?"

"Uh, hi. I'd like to order a cheese pizza...but with no crust," a nervous voice on the other end replied.

Tommy paused, taken aback by the strange request. "A cheese pizza with no crust? You mean like a...cheese pie?"

"Yeah, exactly!" the man on the phone said, chuckling awkwardly. "It's kind of a joke between me and my buddies. We thought it would be funny to order that."

Tommy's eyes narrowed as the wheels started turning in his head. A cheese pizza with no crust was code for a kilo of cocaine, the most popular order they received at the "pizza" shop. 

"Alright, sir, one cheese pizza with no crust, coming right up," Tommy replied, doing his best to keep his voice casual. "Can I get a name for the order?"

"Oh, uh, it's Dave. Dave Simmons."

"Okay, Dave, that'll be $50. We can have that delivered to you in about 30 minutes."

"Great, thanks!" Dave said, and hung up the phone.

Tommy immediately relayed the order to the back, where the real action happened. Within minutes, one of the shop's "delivery drivers" was on his way to Dave's house, a kilogram of pure cocaine hidden in a pizza box.

Dave Simmons had no idea what he was in for. He thought he was just placing a silly pizza order, unaware that he had just stumbled into the middle of a major drug deal. As the driver pulled up to his house, Dave eagerly waited by the front door, ready to share a good laugh with his friends over his "no crust" pizza.

Little did he know, his life was about to change in ways he could never have imagined.', 'The words tumbled out of Mark’s mouth before he could stop them. "Yeah, I'll take a cheese pizza... with no crust." He snickered to himself, picturing the confused face on the other end of the line. Boredom had a way of turning him into a prankster.

"Cheese pizza, no crust," the voice repeated, flat and devoid of humor. "Address?"

Mark gave his address, barely containing his laughter. "And how long will that be?" he asked, already imagining the bewildered delivery driver.

"Thirty minutes," the voice said, and hung up.

Mark chuckled, sinking back into his couch. He flipped through channels, already anticipating telling his friends about the ridiculous pizza he'd ordered. He imagined the pizza joint, a dingy-looking place called "Vinnie's Slice of Heaven," scrambling to fulfil his impossible request.

Thirty minutes later, a nondescript car pulled up outside. A man, built like a brick wall and not wearing a pizza uniform, got out. He carried a large, flat box.

Mark opened the door, expecting a baffled teenager. Instead, he was met with the stern gaze of the brick wall man. "Pizza for Mark?" the man grunted.

"Uh, yeah, that's me," Mark stammered, suddenly feeling less amused.

The man thrust the box into Mark's hands. It was surprisingly heavy. "That'll be fifty," he said, his voice low.

Fifty dollars for no crust? Mark was about to protest when the man fixed him with a look that could curdle milk. He quickly paid, took the box, and shut the door.

Inside, Mark stared at the box. He hesitantly opened it. Instead of a pizza-shaped abyss, he found a tightly sealed package wrapped in several layers of plastic. He poked it cautiously. It was hard, dense, and...powdery?

Panic seized him. He tore at the plastic, his heart hammering in his chest. White powder spilled out, clinging to his fingers. The smell, faint but unmistakable, hit him like a punch to the gut. 

Cocaine.

He stumbled back, dropping the box onto the coffee table. He'd ordered a joke pizza, and ended up with a kilo of cocaine. He’d stumbled into something far beyond his comprehension. Vinnie's Slice of Heaven wasn't serving up cheesy goodness; they were slinging something far more dangerous.

The reality of his situation crashed down on him. He was holding enough drugs to land him in prison for decades. He had to get rid of it. Now.

But as he reached for the phone, a chilling thought struck him. He might have placed the order as a joke, but Vinnie’s might not see it that way. He hadn’t just ordered a pizza, he’d ordered a kilo, and they knew where he lived.
', 'Here is a 470-word short story based on the prompt:

It was a typical Friday night for Michael, sitting on his couch watching reruns of his favorite TV shows and contemplating ordering a pizza for dinner. As he channel surfed, he suddenly had a silly idea. 

"I wonder if I can order a 'cheese pizza with no crust'?" he chuckled to himself. "That's gotta be a new one for the poor pizza delivery guy."

Without further ado, Michael grabbed his phone and called the number for Tony's Pizzeria, his go-to spot for late night deliveries. After a couple rings, a gruff voice answered.

"Tony's Pizzeria, how can I help you?"

"Uh, hi. I'd like to order a cheese pizza, but I want it with no crust," Michael said, trying his best to sound serious.

There was a long pause on the other end of the line. "...A what now?"

"A cheese pizza. With no crust," Michael repeated, barely containing his laughter.

Another pause. "...Sir, I'm not sure that's possible. How would we make a pizza with no crust?"

"I don't know, that's your problem to figure out," Michael said. "Just make it happen, okay? I'm hungry and I really want this weird pizza."

The man on the other end sighed heavily. "Alright, fine. One 'cheese pizza with no crust' coming right up. That'll be $19.99, plus tip. Where do you live?"

Michael gave him his address and waited anxiously for his unusual order to arrive. Part of him wondered if the poor pizza guy would just refuse to make it and hang up, but to his surprise, about 30 minutes later there was a knock at his door.

"Pizza delivery for...Michael?" the young delivery boy said, holding a plain white box.

"That's me!" Michael said, taking the box and handing the boy a $20 bill. "Keep the change."

"Uh, thanks. Enjoy your...pizza," the boy said uncertainly before turning and heading back to his car.

Michael closed the door and eagerly opened the box, expecting to see a hilarious mess of cheese and sauce. Instead, his jaw dropped open in shock. Inside the box was a single, neatly wrapped package of what appeared to be pure cocaine.

"What the...?" Michael stammered, his heart racing. He immediately slammed the box shut and looked around nervously, half expecting the cops to suddenly burst through his front door.

Just then, his phone started ringing. He hesitantly answered it.

"Hello?"

"Listen up, and listen good," a gruff voice said. It was the man from the pizza place. "You weren't supposed to get that package. Forget you ever saw it, understand? If I even think you're going to the cops, we'll be paying you a little visit. This is your one and only warning."

The line went dead, leaving Michael frozen in fear. He stared at the box, his mind racing. He had unwittingly stumbled into a dangerous drug operation, and now his life was at risk. Somehow, he had to find a way to get rid of that package without getting himself killed in the process.']

Name: 35_devil_lucifer_satan_damien
Representative_Docs:
['Here is a short story based on the prompt "The Devil tries to sell his soul to you":

It was a quiet evening when the doorbell rang, interrupting the peaceful silence of my living room. I opened the door to find a tall, imposing figure standing before me. He had a sharp, angular face with piercing eyes and a menacing aura that sent a shiver down my spine.

"Good evening," the stranger said in a deep, velvety voice. "My name is Lucifer, and I have a proposition for you."

I stared at him, unsure of how to respond. The Devil himself, standing on my doorstep? This had to be some kind of trick.

"What kind of proposition?" I asked cautiously.

Lucifer's lips curled into a sinister smile. "I'm in the market to sell my soul. And I've chosen you to be the buyer."

I blinked in disbelief. "You want to sell your soul to me? Why?"

"Because, my dear, I've grown tired of being the ruler of Hell. The endless torment, the never-ending suffering – it's all become rather tedious, you see. I long for a change of pace, a chance to experience the simple joys of mortal life."

I couldn't believe what I was hearing. The Devil, the embodiment of evil, wanted to give up his power and status for a chance at a normal life. It seemed too good to be true.

"But why me?" I asked. "What makes you think I'm the one you want to sell your soul to?"

Lucifer's eyes gleamed with a hint of amusement. "Because, my dear, you possess a rare quality that I find intriguing – a pure heart, untainted by the corruptions of this world. I believe you have the strength to resist the temptations of power and the wisdom to use my soul for the greater good."

I stood there, speechless, as I tried to process the gravity of his words. The thought of owning the Devil's soul was both exhilarating and terrifying.

"What would I have to do in exchange?" I asked, my voice barely above a whisper.

"Nothing," Lucifer replied. "Simply take my soul and use it as you see fit. I only ask that you consider my offer carefully. This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, after all."

I took a deep breath, my mind racing with the implications of this decision. Could I really trust the Devil? Was this all some elaborate trap? But the allure of the power and responsibility was too tempting to ignore.

"Very well," I said, my voice steadier than I felt. "I'll do it."

Lucifer's smile widened, and with a snap of his fingers, a glowing orb appeared in his hand. He extended it towards me, and I reached out, my fingers closing around the pulsating energy.

As the warmth of the soul spread through my body, I knew that my life would never be the same again. I had made a deal with the Devil, and now the fate of the world rested in my hands.', "“ What do you mean you don ’ t know what you want ? ”     “ Well , what ’ ve you got to offer ? ”     “ I-Well there ’ s… ” Lucifer sighed “ *This isn ’ t how it works ! * ”     The man looked on , he could see his brow furrow , his eyes turned skyward as he tried to fathom up a reason for bringing the *literal devil* to his basement . Lucifer could feel his gnarled hands clenching into fists , the temperature of the room cranking up a few notches as steam began emanating from his pores . He wasn ’ t even supposed to be here , not anymore .     Once the human population had started growing rapidly he realised this whole “ Babysitting the damned idiots ” job was a bit more than a one mildly rebellious fallen angel job . So he ’ d made a call back upstairs , telling the big G to poof down some more helpers .   Despite ‘ upper management ’ only sending down what he was pretty sure were the most inept of their already woefully unmotivated workforce , he had managed to rally the ever increasing group together into some semblance of a team , a team whose job was to see to the eternal suffering of every person who ended up down here .     But then these deals started coming , at first he simply chose to ignore them , but as he had given most of the hands-on evil to the rest of his team , he admittedly started taking these deals to fill the void moving into management had left him in , it was almost cathartic , these people were n't already consigned to suffering , he could see the process in action .     Despite there never being a positive outcome more and more people had started requesting him , to the point where he was pretty much constantly flitting from one deal to the other , he started losing track of who had promised what , and it was beginning to get a bit repetitive , a grind . He had his team take over that as well , although he did still tend to a few personal cases of long term clients . The people at the top had been impressed , and his customer service centre has been ranked as the 2nd most evil currently existing , He had given up on catching Comcast .     So , while first confused by Zazuul , his PA , bursting into his office , hands full of blood covered contracts , and explaining they were at capacity , and that they would need everyone taking deals , he was quietly excited . This was a chance to get back into the action , just for a bit .     But it was n't right , the deals just did n't seem the same as before . Normally by the time people had got to ‘ contract with the devil ’ levels of desperation they had a pretty clear idea of what they wanted , but no , he was being given the most mundane requests . “ My car ’ s backfiring ” , “ Could you get me some shopping ? ” and “ I think my cat ’ s sick , it was probably the brand of cat food we bought because my wife said we normally get the green cans and I was like ‘ these are the green cans ’ but they are n't and I think I might be colour-blind ” . How in the name of himself was he supposed to come up with an evil and maniacal solution to a misfed feline ?     And now this guy . **This fucking guy** , had n't even thought of *anything* . He was still just stood there . The fact he was even respiring enough to make Lucifer begin to flame with rage , the heat from him seemed to bring the half-vegetable half-man back from his photosynthetic state , and cause a warm blast of air to fill the room , billowing the mans robes and sending papers from his basement desk flying off of it .   One of these scraps came to rest in front of Lucifer ’ s hooves , and something scrawled upon it caught his eye , the page burned up in his hand before he had even stood up , but it did n't matter , he ’ d seen what was on it .     “ How did you get that ? ! ” Lucifer grabbed the man by the front of his robes ; the smell of burning fabric filled the room . Despite this the man still seemed fairly unphased , tranquil in his stupidity .     “ Huh-I don ’ t-*aaah ! * ” The smoldering robe caught fire , Lucifer tightened his grip on it .     “ This is my personal summons ! ” Real rage was emanating from him now , despite the confined space his voice filled the room like an organ in a church hall . “ I personally give this to a very few trusted people , of which I ’ m certain you aren ’ t one of , *where is this from ? * ” Fire was coming from his mouth now too , close enough to lick the now pale cheeks of the man .     “ I , I really just don ’ t know ! I ’ m sorry ! Someone gave me it ! ” Lucifer could see it in his eyes , he really didn ’ t , great , maybe the next imbecile with a ridiculous deal could shed some light on this . In his rage , and without really thinking , he threw the man across the room .     As his victims limp body slid down the opposite wall , Lucifer looked down to his hand , the rest of the man ’ s robe had been scorched away , but within the ash burned a metal symbol , white hot , an instinct and a revelation made him look up to a now enflamed calendar upon the man ’ s wall . Despite the fire , a now gleaming pen-mark could still be seen , circling a day that Lucifer should never have forgotten . With a pounding of one fist into the other , he blinked out of the basement , knowing exactly where he had to go .     As he blinked into existence , he saw exactly what he had expected to see . A man , stood solitary in black robes , in the middle of a forest clearing , watch in one hand , blood covered contract in the other . As the man turned to see Lucifer standing behind him , he dropped to his knees , pounding the ground with his fist .     “ No ! ” he screamed “ So close ! ” the shout was so extreme it seemed to cast further lines into his already jagged face , being illuminated by Lucifer ’ s own glowing firelight .     “ You were close , Brian , I ’ ll give you that. ” He extended his hand and snatched the contract away from the kneeled man . “ But your ability of persuading others runs out today. ” He could feel himself physically untense as he saw Brian ’ s watch read fifteen minutes to midnight , plenty of time .     “ Who was it ? Who told you ? ”     “ Oh , no one told me ” , Lucifer replied , his trademark sneer returning to his face “ One of your more idiotic followers left his robes on , and my summons scrawled on a piece of paper . I saw the emblem on it , *your emblem* , and brought it back here , where I knew you ’ d be waiting to burn our agreement. ”     Brian dropped his head , holding it in his wrinkled hands . Lucifer continued , “ I know that ’ s a lot to take in , but tell me , how did you do it ? The people calling me personally obviously you gave my summons , but what about the rest of my staff ? What happened to them ? ”   All of a sudden , Brian lowered his hands and cracked a sly smile “ Isn ’ t it obvious ? ” He looked up at Lucifer , straightening his back . “ I published the ritual on the internet. ”     “ The what now ? ” He hoped this wasn ’ t one of those modern inventions that humanity had a habit of concocting every so often , he had just gotten his head round people getting sent his way for sitting watching a small electric box for most of their lives , if it was up to him sloth would be taken off the list of seven sins , along with pride , that one never made sense .     Realising he ’ d drifted off into his own thoughts , he looked up just in time to see Brian make a grab for the contract , he moved it away , still looking at him for an explanation . Brian slouched back down , seemingly accepting defeat for the final time .     “ You should probably look it up , it ’ s going to be sending a lot more people your way. ” Brian said with a derisive snort of laughter .     “ Well whatever it is , that plan is still pretty despicable , and it explains all the half-baked ideas from everyone I visited. ”     “ I still can ’ t believe one of my men left his *robes on*. ” He was staring forwards , perplexed . You know , I try and man manage but with some people it just seems completely impossible ”     Lucifer let a small smile appear across his face “ So right , you know when you just feel like ‘ I have too many staff ’ ”     Brian got to his feet “ Completely , how am I supposed to keep everyone in check when I ’ ve got tens of people joining a day , not realistic , and I can ’ t find anyone with enough aptitude to hire on as an assistant. ”     Lucifer was about to agree , when his brow furrowed “ Yea… ” an idea occurred to him , “ Hey…I know I ’ m supposed to drag you to hell now and everything , but I think I could use more men , well , *A man* like you downstairs…what do you say ?     A truly despicable smirk rose across Brian ’ s face , not to dissimilar to the devil ’ s own , and he grabbed Lucifer ’ s hand with an almost inhuman enthusiasm , saying…     “ You , my good friend , have a deal. ”     Edit : Grammar  ", '“ Let me get this straight , ” I said , leaning back in my chair to take in the glorious clusterfuck of person standing before me . “ You are the Devil . Satan , Lucifer , Beelzeboss . The master of all evil , the Beast from below . You are the one and only incarnation of absolute despair and horrific torture. ”     The bearded man twitched , nodded , wiped his nose with his thumb .     “ And you ’ re broke. ”     “ Penniless as the day I was born , ” the Devil said .     “ The day you were -- ” I shook my head . “ Why on Earth would the Devil need money ? ”     “ Well , ‘ on Earth ’ is where you ’ re wrong , ” the Devil said . “ The place I ’ d be spending it would be Hell , obviously . Economy ’ s really crashing hard down there , see. ”     “ And how exactly would earthly money be any help in that scenario ? ”     The Devil shrugged . “ The rules of Heaven and Hell are… really a lot different than people think. ”     “ Oh , really ? What ’ s the exchange rate between the Euro and the Hell Dollar ? ”     “ Actually , there is no ‘ Hell Dollar. ’ We deal in souls. ”     I blinked . “ Obviously. ” My eyes narrowed as I realized what that meant . “ So if I actually paid you to acquire your soul… you would have to exchange that money into souls , right ? You ’ d go around and use it to buy other people ’ s souls , which you can then use as currency in Hell. ”     The Devil nodded . “ Precisely. ”     I threw up my hands in speechless exasperation .     “ Look , ” the Devil said , “ If you don ’ t want to pay for it , there are other methods of trade . Do you perchance play the fiddle ? We could fiddle for each others ’ souls , if you ’ d -- ”     “ No , I don ’ t play the fucking fiddle ! ” The Devil flinched slightly at my outburst . “ What is up with you , anyway ? Aren ’ t you supposed to be some kind of huge , horned beast with goat hoofs ? Aren ’ t you supposed to be going around , killing babies or… something ? ”     “ K-killing babies ? ” the Devil said . “ That ’ s a bit dark , don ’ t you think ? ”     I stared at him , incredulous . “ I ’ m talking to a crazy hobo off the street again , aren ’ t I ? ” I murmured . “ I got ta stop doing that… ”     “ No , no , ” the Devil said . “ I assure you , I am one hundred percent authentic fallen angel. ”     “ Then why are you so… unimposing ? ”     “ Look , ” the Devil said , eyelid twitching , fingers fidgeting . “ Demons need souls to feed the fires of rage and hatred within them . I am the top demon , so I need… a lot of souls . So right now , as I am completely broke , and I have no souls to feed on , I… am kind of a weakling. ”     “ Yeah , ” I snorted . “ Not an understatement at all. ” I rubbed my temples , trying to make sense of the situation and calm my nerves .     “ So you want me to buy your soul for , what , a couple thousand dollars , and -- ”     “ A couple hundred would be fine , actually. ”     “ Well , don ’ t drive the price down , you idiot ! ” I said . “ You haven ’ t even made your case yet ! ”     “ Sorry , ” he said . “ Look , let me make this offer a little more attractive to you. ”     “ Oh , yeah , please do. ”     “ A demon ’ s soul is somewhat different from that of a human or angel . It contains the unholy power that drives us , but it also needs to bet kept alive through the sacrifice of other souls . Now , if you owned my soul , I would be forever bound to your being . I would not be able to do a thing without your consent , and if you wanted me to die , all you ’ d have to do was stop feeding my soul. ”     “ Uh-huh , ” I said . “ So if I wanted you to die , thus freeing this world and the next of your tyranny and preventing the biblical apocalypse , I could just… do that ? ”     “ Yes. ”     “ Huh. ” That seemed a little too good to be true . There was no way the Devil was desperate enough to put his very existence into the hands of a mortal . *The soul would probably corrupt me* , I thought . *He knows I won ’ t kill him , because the power of his soul would consume me and force me to do his will . * Despite his meek appearance , he was still trying to trick me . I would not fall for it .     “ But ! ” The Devil held up a finger and pulled me out of my train of thought . “ There are bonuses ! If you owned my soul , you would gain various superhuman powers , including flight , super strength , telekinesis… anything , really ! ”     “ Leave my apartment , ” I said . “ Go find someone else to harass , Lucifer . I ’ m not biting. ”     He hesitated , then nodded . “ Very well. ” Slowly , he padded backward , but stopped at the door . “ You would receive incredible power , ” he said . “ Greater than your wildest fantasies. ”     “ Damn it , demon ! ” I slammed my hand on the table . “ Tell me one thing , then ! ”     He raised an eyebrow . “ Yes ? ”     “ Would I get laser vision ? ”     “ I… I ’ m not sure what you mean. ”     “ Would I be able to shoot lasers out of my eyes ? ”     The Devil smirked hesitantly . “ Yes . Yes , you would. ”     “ Hmm. ” I scratched my chin . Then , I sighed , and waved at him dismissively . “ Fine . I ’ ll think about it. ”     -- -- -     Edit : typo']

Name: 36_my_the_it_was
Representative_Docs:
['Every morning, the sound of the trains rattling against the tracks served as my alarm clock. I would shuffle to the bathroom, brush my teeth, and pull on my corporate attire like a second skin before trudging out the door. My mornings hadn’t changed much since I started working at Hartley & Associates two years ago; the routine was as predictable as the weather. Coffee, commute, and a long day in the cubicle. But lately, something peculiar had disrupted my monotony. 

It all began a week ago when I discovered the lunch. I opened the employee fridge, warily peering past the mound of takeout containers and half-eaten sandwiches that seemed to have developed personalities of their own. Nestled among them was a pristine Tupperware container with my name scrawled on a blue sticky note. 

“Gabe,” it read in neat, curling letters. 

Curiosity piqued, I hesitated for a moment before plucking it from its cold home. Inside, I discovered a perfectly crafted turkey sandwich, sliced diagonally, accompanied by a side of fresh, vibrant grapes and a small bag of homemade potato chips. The delightful aroma wafted toward me, as if coaxing me to indulge. I tore into the meal, and to my surprise, my taste buds erupted with joy. The sandwich was seasoned to perfection, the bread soft and fresh. 

Day by day, the lunches continued to appear, each more delicious than the last. There was a zesty pasta salad with sun-dried tomatoes one day, a rich quinoa bowl with roasted vegetables the next, and even a slice of homemade carrot cake that left me blissful. My lunch hour transformed from a dreary routine to a treasure hunt. Each bite filled with intrigue and a growing desire to uncover the identity of the kindly chef behind the mystery. 

As the days rolled into weeks, I became obsessed, my mind racing with possibilities. Could it be Clara, the soft-spoken accountant with a penchant for baking? Or perhaps Liam from marketing, who always had a hidden stash of gourmet snacks? I sought clues, keeping my eyes peeled for any telltale signs, but the identity of my lunch angel remained elusive.

One Thursday, the unthinkable happened. A note accompanied my usual feast. “I hope you enjoy! Keep smiling, Gabe.” The signature was simple: “-A.” It was personal, direct. My heart raced. I never imagined someone at work would take such care to brighten my days. But who was “A”? 

Determined to uncover the truth, I began a discreet investigation. I observed the other employees’ lunch habits, searched for hints in their conversations, but my quest yielded nothing. It was as if “A” was a ghost, silently cheering me on from the shadows. 

Then, during a particularly exhausting meeting that stretched into an even longer afternoon, I felt a tap on my shoulder. Turning, I found Amelia, the quiet intern whose shy smile always lit up the room. 

“Gabe,” she said, her voice barely above a whisper. “I made your lunch today.” 

A rush of warmth flooded through me. The mystery had a face, and it was one of genuine kindness. 

“Thank you, Amelia,” I grinned, my heart swelling. “You’ve made my workdays something special.” 

Her cheeks flushed, and from that point on, each meticulously packed lunch was not just a meal but a bridge, drawing me closer to the one who saw beyond the mundane duties of the office. 

In a world of sterile cubicles and routine tasks, I found nourishment that went beyond food—the warmth of human connection hidden within the confines of a corporate fridge.', 'Here is a 451 word short story based on the prompt:

The Mystery Lunch

It was a Monday morning, the start of another long work week. As I shuffled into the office kitchen, the familiar sight of my name scrawled on a neatly packed lunch box caught my eye. I paused, staring at it quizzically. This had been happening for weeks now, but I still couldn't figure out who was leaving this lunch for me.

I glanced around the empty kitchen, as if expecting the culprit to materialize out of thin air. But alas, I was alone. With a shrug, I grabbed the lunch box and headed back to my desk.

Opening it up, I was met with an array of delicious-looking homemade foods. There was a fresh salad, a thermos of soup, a sandwich on artisanal bread, and even a small dessert. Someone had clearly put a lot of time and effort into preparing this.

As I ate, I couldn't help but wonder who was behind this. Was it a kind-hearted coworker, trying to make my life a little easier? Or perhaps a secret admirer, leaving me these meals as a way to get my attention? The possibilities swirled in my mind.

Over the next few days, the mystery lunch continued to appear. Each one was different, but always perfectly tailored to my tastes. I began to look forward to these meals, savoring every bite. They were a bright spot in an otherwise dreary work day.

Finally, on Friday, I decided to get to the bottom of this. As I was placing the empty lunch box back in the fridge, I noticed a small note tucked underneath.

"I hope you've been enjoying the lunches. I just wanted to do something nice for you. Have a wonderful weekend!"

The note wasn't signed, but the handwriting was unmistakable. It was my boss, Janet. I felt a rush of affection and gratitude towards her. What a thoughtful and unexpected gesture.

From that day on, I made sure to thank Janet every time a new lunch appeared. She would just smile and say it was her pleasure. I never did find out exactly why she started doing this for me, but I didn't really need to know. The important thing was that it made me feel cared for and appreciated.

Those mystery lunches were a reminder that even in the midst of the daily grind, there are people out there who are willing to go the extra mile to brighten someone's day. It was a gesture of kindness that I will always remember.', "I woke up and went to brush my teeth ; I ran out of paste two weeks ago , default was supposed to be flavourless , but tasted like grit , mint was a premium item . My apartment was dark , messy and a little dungeony , but it had it 's advantages , I punched the buttons on the food fabricator for breakfast . The 'oat ' bar ' : protein printed to have the feel of what people imagine oats would taste like , glazed with sugar . It was still warm to from the printer , just like mom used to synth .     I sit down , put the headset on and log in . My world becomes bright and clean . I turn on augment mode and the walls of my apartment have wood panelling , the door is now a bookcase full of the classics . I look at the sealed up window and it 's been replaced by a view of the city . A real view may cost extra , but a cyber sim of it is free . The major landmarks are highlighted , and there is an overlay of current traffic . The full auto lanes are running like clockwork , while the manual roads are jammed as expected . I do n't even know where those people are n't going , its not like most them have a job .     Automation . From everything from farming down to underwriting insurance . Pretty much anyone can be automated , which means most things were . A machine does n't require sleep , time off , or sick leave . A machine does n't talk at the coffee machine for 10 minutes .     Highly skilled engineers and anyone who knew anything about robots did well . Even hobbyists could make a decent living filling need gaps large solutions left ; like prosthetics for an 8 year old who will outgrow it in a year . Software and 'cyber ' did well in all this .     Unemployment increased , the news in my display told me it had hit a new record , 65 % , and this was being hailed as a good thing . As everything became automated , the costs of most living expenses came down , but so did the ability for people to buy it . This is when the UNIVERSAL system was rolled out .     UNIVERSAL was a massive undertaking , showing all the benefits of automation . Housing projects hundreds of feet high , with free automated food processors in every room . Residents would also be given a weekly number of credits , these could be spent at any of the stores within any UNIVERSAL project . This was the way of the future ; meet peoples basic needs for next to no cost . The cost , was in your metadata . This was given to software , which would use it to learn about needs better , and cater better for them .     I knew what I was in for when I signed up . Outside of credits , I had no money making me trapped in whatever UNIVERSAL decided . The first people they let live as they wanted , even catering to moving them to a floor with a better view when they got bored . They had food and clothing fabricators that could create pretty much anything under the sun in seconds . They had a connection to the internet for anything else they needed . They did n't have to work , they could study , be artists , anything they wanted , life was good , and it was only costing people their data .     Outside of the display UNIVERAL tower they showed , things became very different . Premium they called it . They bolted the windows shut by default and removed the glass , a view became premium . The fabricator was restricted to food that would keep you alive , other items were premium , clothes were dull colours unless you got a premium one . The people almost rioted ove that one , but do you know what stops a riot ? Every automated shop that takes credits closing , every vending machine going out of order , and every fabricator stopping . Ends even faster when they turn the water off .     That was another premium , hot water . Many residents took to using a kettle to heat it themselves . The plugs in later buildings were upgraded to only take UNIVERSAL products . Universal do not sell a kettle .     I should make it clear you did n't buy any of these features . They were timed . Rent a view for a week at a time . Hourly rates for the fabricator . Hot water metered down to the millilitre . A thousand other tiny things used few credits , fractions of a credit at a time .     All of these things could be bought with real money of course , it 's just most people in UNIVERSAL did n't have any . This drive most to look for a job of any sort . The black market grew , and before long people were modifying units to do things they had not taken premium for . All of this had a cost , and quickly protection rackets grew , who 'd hack the systems so they wouldn ' detect your mods . Do n't keep up to date on that subscription , and UNIVERSAL will detect the mods . 'Terms of Service Breach ' sounds much nicer to being evicted , made homeless and being charged with damaging company property .     For money most tried to create something machines could not , nice pattered glass , intricate earrings , generally anything that filled a niche . Others used media to get supporters who 'd pay them to create content for them to consume ; new VR augment , new altered reality app , recreating a movie inside a game to live through , a million weird and brilliant things . There were some very talented people out there . Most of the stuff out there was terrible , best way was to get on the top charts of UNIVERSALs app store .     The rest had to get jobs it was hard for a computer to do . Checking the computers were working correctly was the main one . Checking they were doing what they were supposed to , general tech support , front-line easy stuff for the most part .     There were a bunch of reclamation projects on old oil rigs and flooded cities , claiming it was n't worth getting a robot to do , when they get a bunch of cheap labour there for a few dollars and a fabricator . There were a lot of jobs around the ocean and coastlines , a lot of demolition work . Really I think it was just to give those looking something to fight to do . It ca n't be hard to get a machine to do that work .     I look at the virtual city for a second more , I sit at my desk , clearing a few bottles away while opening my streaming app , and I connected to the producer as became a solid bright light , I was in a TV studio . I checked my avatar and signalled I was ready . The countdown started .     I took a deep breath . `` Welcome to Motorola-Fox News . ''"]

Name: 37_my_the_me_and
Representative_Docs:
['Here is a short story based on the prompt:

The darkness enveloped me as I trudged along the deserted mountain road, the only sound the crunch of gravel beneath my feet. My car had broken down miles from the nearest town, and I had no choice but to walk for help. 

As I walked, the hairs on the back of my neck began to rise. I had the unsettling feeling that I was being watched. Glancing around nervously, I saw nothing but the impenetrable blackness of the night. Still, the sensation persisted.

Picking up my pace, I strained my eyes, desperately searching for any sign of civilization in the distance. But the road stretched on endlessly, surrounded by dense forest on either side. 

Suddenly, a twig snapped in the trees behind me. I whirled around, my heart pounding in my chest. At first, I saw nothing. Then, a pair of glowing eyes emerged from the darkness, reflecting the faint starlight.

I froze, my breath catching in my throat. Whatever it was, it was moving closer, slowly and deliberately. I could make out a large, hulking shape, prowling towards me on all fours. 

As it drew nearer, I caught a glimpse of matted fur and sharp, gleaming teeth. My mind raced - bear? Cougar? Wolf? Whatever it was, I knew I had to get away. 

Turning, I broke into a desperate sprint, my legs pumping as fast as they could carry me. The creature gave chase, its heavy footfalls pounding the ground behind me. I could hear its guttural snarls, feel its hot breath on the back of my neck.

Ahead, I spotted an old wooden fence, partially obscured by overgrown brush. Without slowing, I leapt over it, landing hard on the other side. The creature crashed into the fence, snarling in frustration as it tried to clamber over.

I kept running, putting as much distance between myself and the beast as possible. Finally, I caught sight of a flickering light in the distance - a farmhouse. Mustering the last of my strength, I sprinted towards it, not daring to look back.

By the time I reached the house, I was gasping for breath, my lungs burning. I pounded frantically on the door, begging for help. After what felt like an eternity, the door swung open, revealing a grizzled old farmer holding a shotgun.

"Please, there's some kind of creature out there!" I cried. "It was chasing me!"

The farmer's eyes narrowed as he took in my disheveled appearance. "You best come on in, son," he said gruffly, ushering me inside and bolting the door behind us.

As I caught my breath, I glanced out the window, half-expecting to see the glowing eyes staring back at me. But the road was empty, save for the gentle sway of the fence in the night breeze.
